Inside, in fact, the unfinished wooden walls kinda gave me a feel of being inside a barn.  But in a warm, cozy way.... One side of the restaurant featured a lengthy bar with a couple of plasma screen TVs for patrons waiting, or just drinking & mixing, to sit and enjoy.  The other side of the establishment had seating.  While we were there, it got QUITE crowded and noisy.  We actually had to start shouting over the din to hear each other towards the end of our dinner.  But it seemed like more of a place to mix and talk and enjoy.

THE MENU

I love CHEESE!  I love MELTED Cheese!  So it goes without saying that I love CHEESE FONDUE... mmmm....  The offerings covered a nice variety too:

The Traditional Fondue is a mix of swiss gruyere, emmenthaler, white wine, and spiced with roasted garlic, fresh ground nutmeg     
 
The Outlaw is a combination of aged cheddar, beer, slow roasted tomatoes, and spiced with roasted garlic, roasted jalapeno, cilantro  
    
The Stage Coach mixes compte cheese, white wine, and is also spiced with roasted garlic      

The Quick Draw features manchego, white wine, roasted red puree, and is also spiced with roasted garlic   
   
And the Rawhide melts italian dolce gorgonzola, emmenthaler, white wine base together and is spiced with bacon and roasted garlic.

These fondues are each $18 and they come with substantial amount and mix of Roasted Potatoes, Sourbread sections, Fresh Broccoli, cut Apples and Olives.

We just ordered the first TWO (2) on the menu (The Traditional Fondue and the Outlaw Fondue) and we had at it.  I reserved my share of apples for the end and chose not to dip that in cheese, but every thing else was fair game and delicious.  

I think for me the best sensual experience about the fondue is the delicious fragrance of the heated wine and melted cheese together.  It really fires up the taste buds if done right, and these 2 selections were absolutely magnificent in charging up my tongue.

I had tongue-gasm one right after another with each delicious bite.

There were also a selection of meat fondues and dessert fondues, but we were just cheese-purists this night.

THE LOWDOWN

If you really want to satisfy your "cheese craving" in a pretty spectacular way, a trek to Fondue Cowboy will appeal to all of your senses as well as your appetite!
author: Michelangelo S.

description:
This place was probably the worst restaurant I've been to in the last few months if not this year.

To start off the building is far too small for the amount of tables they have. The acoustics are so bad that you can barely hear the person across from you speak when it's busy.

Before we were seated, there was a few minute wait. A wait that ended up being less than the one we had to even see our waiter again and that one even less than the wait before we were served our food. 

Food I might add that beyond one item, did not need to be cooked.

The cheese, had I not been moderately tipsy on sparkling wine, would have been inedible. I ended up sticking to the cubed apples which tasted of the Gherkin's next to them (which I can't stand) and the bread, some of which was dry and oily. The sausage was good until my dinner partner mentioned it tasted exactly like a hot dog, after which I realized I had just paid 40 dollars for a meal I could have easily made at home.

Drunken yelping for places that sound interesting is never a good plan.

2 stars.
author: Meg T.

description:
Yeeeeeeee haaaaaaaaaa!  Giddyup!

This is a cool spot and the staff is really friendly.  The inside is modern and you just feel cool eating here :)  There are a couple of issues though. 1. You have to order the sausage slices in order to be full and trust me they are delicious. 2. They could have a lot more creative ideas for the dessert items to dunk into their chocolate.  The chocolate cake pieces are no more then chocolate bread chunks. (You will understand when you eat there)

SUPER EXPENSIVE!  I cannot in good conscience give this place 4 stars and it really is only a 3.5 star place for me because of the cost.  It is good but unfortunately the cost will probably prevent me from going back anytime soon.  For two people, be prepared to spend $80.00 :(
author: Brian S.

description: Had the most delicious savory and sweet Fondue. Tried the outlaw as it was recommended in most reviews and turned out to be amazingly delicious. Went with dark chocolate - happy trails , sweet fondue and it was soooo yummy. The side dips for both the fondues were fresh. Nice cozy ambience and good food. Would definitely recommend!!!
author: Manasi O.

description:
This was SUCH a fun dinner! The owner was a wonderful host and the food was great. We had two fondues, the traditional one with emmenthaler, and the cheddar/beer one. There would more dippable accompaniments (olives! potatoes! grapes!) than I expected, but they all totally worked! YUM! And we added the top sirloin side, and it was so delish! We had the chocolate walnut fondue for dessert, which was also really wonderful. I definitely plan to go back. And back!

BTW, the ambiance is fab, too!

Looks  like there's only street parking here.
author: Karen Z.

description: A must try if you're in the area and you aren't lactose intolerant. Service was very good and the menu options were fun but can become a bit much. Cool environment and I like the location. Give their Happy Hour a try!
author: Annette S.

description:
Fondue Cowboy would get 5 stars if they gave a better portion of cheese. My sister and I got "The Outlaw" and added the Cured Slice Meats, and everything was delicious, but it just wasn't enough cheese for all the food they give you.

For dessert we got the "Buck-a-Roo" which is the milk chocolate fondue. In addition to fresh fruits, they gave us a large plate of bread? We didn't eat the bread with the chocolate, but I probably wouldn't get the fondue dessert next time. 

The sangria was reallllllllly good. I definitely recommend this place. Make a reservation though, very limited seating.
author: Felicia R.

description:
As a Swiss native, I'm always looking for fun fondue experiences, and I'd say Fondue Cowboy is much more of a fon-'do' than a fon-'don't'.  (Sorry.)

I've been here a couple of times in groups of 2-4 people, and everyone's always been pretty pleased.  It's not in a great neighborhood, so I don't recommend walking there alone at night if possible.  Fortunately, it's just a few blocks from the good part of SoMa.

I've enjoyed both the Traditional Swiss and Quick Draw (which has roasted peppers and garlic) cheese fondues, as well as the Buck-A-Roo (milk chocolate with walnuts) fondue for dessert.  I do wish they had a more 'simple' chocolate fondue, since I'm not particularly a fan of walnuts or cayenne (The Melting Point has a fantastic one with oreo pieces that I looove).  However, I guess they're sticking with the Western theme of the restaurant, and that's not a bad thing.

The vibe is funky and the service has been good every time I've been.  It's a small restaurant, and I do recommend making a reservation before you go, just to avoid going out of your way and ending up disappointed.
author: Joëlle M.

description:
I love cheese! This was my first time trying fondue at a restaurant and I was pretty surprised. Came here with a friend, so there was the two of us and we ordered one pot of The outlaw (which was delicious and the jalapeno was definitely there, but not spicy).. and the meat platter that comes with three types of meat. The fondue itself comes with roasted potatoes, bread, broccoli, grapes, honey dew, cantaloupe, and I forget the other stuff but there is a good amount of stuff to dip in the delicious cheeseeeeee. It was a good amount for the two of us and we even had left over items. The staff is friendly and very helpful if and when you order.
Also $5 beers (on tap) can't go wrong!
author: Tiff C.

description: Fondue spot is a hidden gem and worth every penny! I was impressed on the cocktails, service, and the ambiance. I suggest trying a app, entree to share, and save room for dessert if you can haha! I can't wait to go back.
author: K M.

description: This place is such a little Gem and I'm soo excited we found it!  We had the Stage Coach and the Sausage for our main course which was plenty for two people. And, then we had the Buck-A-Roo for desert and it was all soo delicious! I loved the potatoes with the cheese and the Marshmallows for desert were To Die For! We will definitely be coming back and I would love to have my bday dinner hear as it has such a cozy, friendly atmosphere :)
author: Samantha H.

description: Whatever i say for this restaurant wont do it justice. Where can i start? THIS IS BY FAR THE BEST FOOD I HAVE EVER TASTED. I AM HONESTLY ADDICTED TO IT. If i could i would only eat they're food. The owners are just AMAZING. Me and my fiance we go 2-3 times per week or more. we love it so so much. the place is nice, very cozy and clean, you can see the chefs when they prepare your food its all so lovely. I have noticed some people dont order the chocolate fondue and i feel like i need to tell them what they are missing. for me the MILK CHOCOLATE FONDUE is just PE RFE CTION. its honestly the best dessert i have ever tried. i dont understand how people dont order dessert. Anyway i just love this place so much and whatever i say wont do it justice. Yall need to go and check it out to understand what i am talking about.
author: Lne V.

description:
Well ... first .. I must say .. the place is really nice ... nice bar and the service is really fine ...
The prices of the "fondues" is ok ... 25 $ for a 2 serve portion .. and it comes with veggies, potatoes, fruits, bread. 
If you are really hungry you can order a plate of sausage ...it's 8$ so .. still cheap ... 

The main problem (and it's easy to understand why the fondue is so cheap) is that .. it's not really fondue ... it's more like a warm dip with cheesy taste ! 

A real fondue is only cheese and wine/garlic/peppercorn .... at cowboy fondue ... it's more a thick sauce ... and it's easy to see it .. when you dip your bread in a fondue .. the bread leaves the cheese string on the fork ... and it doesn't happen at the cowboy fondue  ! 

The taste was ok, we had 2 different "fondues" ..... couldn't say it wasn't bad .. but couldn't say it was a real fondue either ... 

I would just recommend to the cheese lovers to go to the melting pot instead (ok .. it's more expensive) ... but there you'll have real fondues ! 

Anyway we did spend a nice evening ... 

We didn't try the chocolate fondues ... who looked way better !
author: Nicolas D.

description:
I am beyond impressed.

We arrived, kids in tow, around 6:30 on a Friday night without a reservation (like complete SanFran noobs) and one of the servers informed us nicely that they were completely booked. I kicked myself for not calling ahead.

We hung our heads and walked back out to our car, and hubby and I pulled out our phones to begin the yelp search all over again, from scratch. A few minutes went by, when that server came running out, all the way across the street to our car, motioning to us. When I rolled down the window he said, "Actually, we just had a table open up, if you still want it. It'll be ready in about 10 minutes. I'm so sorry I made you walk all the way out here just to have you come back in!"

Ummm, you're sorry? You just saved our evening! You absolutely did not need to go out of your way to remedy OUR failure to make reservations. Wow... I see a very large tip in your future.

We sat on a bench outside the little restaurant to wait, and someone brought some menus out to us and patiently explained the menu and gave us tips on what the kids might like.

Let's just say, the rest of the night only got better from there.

We had the Stagecoach with the sausage side plate, and the High Noon for dessert. Everything was incredible. Our boys (ages 4 and 7) picked at the fruit, bread and meat like little birds (which is how they always eat) and we were able to enjoy most of the (incredible) fondue by ourselves. The dipping pieces are refillable, so everyone was able to eat their fill at a reasonable cost. When the dessert came out, the boys turned up their noses at it just like they had at the cheese fondue, and it took a little convincing (why did I bother??) to get them to believe that it was CHOCOLATE and they would like it. Anyway, eventually they did try it and after that I think I maybe got one or two bites in. Haha.

The Yelp info above states this is NOT a good place for kids, but we really had a great time. Fondue is a wonderful experience for anyone, kids included. (Particularly if your kids are calm, well-behaved, and thrilled about eating grapes, bread cubes, and sausage slices for dinner.) ;)

It is a rather small restaurant (maybe 8-10 tables), so plan ahead and make reservations. Definitely an ideal date-night spot. I'm already planning our next trip... WITHOUT the kids.
author: Kristi D.

description:
First impression of the place was "Wow, fancy". Despite the small size of the room, the dimmed light and the bar made it feel a bit luxurious. My friend and I ordered the Traditional and the High Noon fondues. We were not impressed with the Traditional. The cheese was melted but it was not as smooth as I expected but rather lumpy. Maybe I'm just not cut out for cheese fondue but it felt to me a bit bland. Out of all the sides that were given, the grapes and apples went the best with the cheese. 
High Noon, though, was a different story. The sweet white chocolate was magical. It went well with all the sides and the sides were DELICOUS. Most people like the chocolate bread but for me it was the marshmallows. They were heavenly. I have never had such soft and buttery marshmallows in my life. 
Service was great and the waiter was super friendly. I would come back for the chcolate.
author: Nausicca Y.

description: Best Fondue place in San Francisco by far! Great atmosphere , wine and other drinks. The food is phenomenal! Must go!
author: Juan S.

description: This place is amazing!!! The staff here is so helpful and amazing. I have Celiacs and they helped me through the menu and made me special sauce that I could eat. Just amazing!
author: Tiffany O.

description:
Cheese on cheese on cheese!

My friends took me here for my birthday and aside from a mediocre bottle of Malbec, everything was great.

After reading other Yelp reviews, I thought the place might be too hipster for my taste, but I was pleasantly surprised. Not a hint of pretense, and a classy atmosphere.

We ordered nearly every item on the menu and my favorites were the salumi plate, blue cheese fondue, and dark chocolate cayenne fondue (heaven). 

Great for an intimate meal! Just don't plan on going out dancing afterwards. The cheese coma is stronger than you are. Trust me.
author: Lauren R.

description:
The last fondue spot we dined in, portions were much too large for the two of us. And because it was a bit pricey we felt it was huge waste throwing the rest out. So we continued to eat. We ate and ate until we're absolutely repulsed of cheese and didn't care to see it for a good MONTH. This was about 4 years ago and we have not visited a fondue place up until a week or so ago when we decided to try Fondue Cowboy. 

Here, the two of us were able to finish both the cheese and chocolate fondues and we each had a beer to wash it all down. We were recommended to try their beer infused cheddar with garlic and jalapeño from our waiter and we were definately not let down by his recommendation. Hubs decided to add on a sausage plate  We were very happy with what we ordered as it was exactly what we wanted/expected. And portions were just right to share with one other.

Definately leave space for the dessert fondue. We had the Happy Trails which was dark chocolate with cayenne pepper. It accompanied bite size pieces of chocolate bread, cut up madelines cookies, home made marshmallows (we asked for extra and they happily gave it to us), grapes, strawberries and bananas. It was devoured in no time.
author: Esther A.

description:
I've been here a few times since they first opened. They never fail to impress me with the food and wine list. 

The salads are huge - this time we had one with arugula, goat cheese, and golden beets. 

I've had a few of the fondues, and the presentation with pickles, grapes, potatoes, broccoli, apples, and olives in addition to bread makes for a very filling meal. I don't think I've ever made it to dessert, although it looks amazing. 

Reservations on Open Table are a huge plus, although this last time they gave away our table because we were five minutes late (thanks, MUN), they were apologetic, offered complimentary drinks while we waited, and seated us almost immediately anyway. Huge points for attentive service. 

Only complaint: it can get very noisy. Little did we know, before 7 pm on Friday  seemed to be unofficially "rant with a group of girlfriends happy hour" at Fondue Cowboy, so keep that in mind if you go in early and don't want to have to shout. The later crowd was more dressed up for quieter, romantic dates.
author: Sam Z.

description:
I'd give this place 4.5 stars but rounded up.  We got the Stage Coach (compte, white wine, sauteed mushrooms, roasted garlic) and the Outlaw (cheddar, beer, roasted tomatoes, garlic, jalapeno, cilantro).  Two fondues were a good portion for 3 people who started with salads.  The Outlaw was the lead contender.  But I think it was because the Stage Coach had a bit too much white wine and it took a few minutes for the white wine to burn off to meld into the rest of the flavors, but then it was just as good.  Fixins' were green apple, grapes, broccoli, gherkins and kalamata olives (and of course bread) which were fine (it's all just a means to get the cheese in your mouth, right?).

The decor was very modern so I don't know what makes this place very cowboy except the fondue names, a painted Clint Eastwood on one wall, and a sheriff star in their logo, but ultimately it sticks in your mind and piques the interest of diners so it works.  The lights are turned down low, you're staring into your companions' eyes flickering with the candlelight warming the fondue, and the steamin' cheese and chocolate make the windows fog up like memories of make out sessions in the back seat of your car.  So I guess it's romantic.

Really, the whole point of eating for me is to get to dessert and the dark chocolate fondue with cayenne called Happy Trails was definitely worth it.  And the dippins of chocolate sourdough, boutique marshmallows and madeleines were perfect.  So yes, I'll be back--'Happy Trails to you, until we meet again...'  Oh yes, we will meet again...!

Cons: I can see why people ding the ratings for the value at $18/savory fondue and $16/sweet but that includes the goodies to dip.  Just wine and beer.  Other than cheese, chocolate and salads, your SOL but I went with a lactose-intolerant vegetarian and she had a great time.

Pros: Good parking, good service.  Melted cheese.  Melted chocolate.  What more do you want?
author: kiwi l.

description:
Based on yelp comments we picked this place for our anniversary dinner.
Love the ambiance. Service is great. We tried classic fondue and it lacked some flavor. We are fondue fans and made it from scratch at home many times. 
When you eat fondue you should have melted cheese strings dragging after you dip your bread or other things, this one didn't do that. It is more like very dense alfredo dip. Also it was served in colder temperature then expected. Awesome sides, I wish they had mushrooms for dipping as well.
I think you can find a better tasting fondue in an another restaurant, Matterhorn,, but ambiance in Fondue Cowboy takes over and adds what was lost in the food flavor. I wish I could give 5 stars.

To the owners, please work on your classic fondue taste it lacks flavor!
author: Lana P.

description:
I recently went to Fondue Cowboy with my boyfriend and had a great time. It's a great ambiance and there are not many other places like it. We went during a weekday so we didn't have a problem getting seated but I can imagine that over the weekends they get pretty swarmed as their is not a whole lot of seating.

Would go here again!
author: Tessa V.

description:
"Hi everybody!...I'm Glen Campbell!"
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=atHY8rDBhtI

I've been walkin' these streets for days
Eatin' at the same old cafes
I know every crack on the tired sidewalks of Folsom
Where hustle's the name of the game
And nice places get washed away like urine and rain
There's been a load of compromisin'
On the road to my horizon
But I'm gonna be where the cheese is meltin' for me

Like a fondue cowboy
Loungin' out on a bench in a star-spangled halter top
Like a fondue cowboy
Chewin' chunks of bread with skinny people I don't even know
And offers comin' under the stall

Fondue Cowboy actually feeds off a concept older than "Rhinestone Cowboy". Except for Fondue Fred in Berkeley back during my mullet-and-doobie days, I honestly couldn't tell you the last time I had a hankering for fondue. To me, pots of melted cheese with skewers immediately conjure up images of Aspen ski chalets, white turtlenecks, guys named Sven, and Claudine Longet shooting her lover.

Sure enough, that's what they serve here albeit in a more contemporary, minimalist setting. Jamie W. and I went to a pre-opening party for the locals to sample most of their fondues, and my diagnosis was that they were good enough for a return visit. Perhaps I have a mental bloc about this, but I simply don't consider fondue the makings of a whole dinner despite the encouragement of the waiter to order two cheese pots and a chocolate one.

We just went for the $15 Outlaw, which consisted of a small pot of melted aged cheddar, beer, slow-roasted tomatoes, roasted garlic and jalapeno and a smidgen of cilantro, all simmering over a candle. There were two little plates of food in which we were to poke our skewers. One had the chunks of bread , baguette slices and halved baby potatoes. The other had mini-broccoli florets, picked grapes, chunks of apples and cornichons (see photo).

It was all tasty enough to be a satisfying appetizer for two, which was exactly what we were looking for anyway. The Western theme with the giddy-up names of the fondue pots is amusing if a bit coy. They were even playing a high-def version of "A Fistful of Dollars" on the big screen behind the counter. I have to wonder how long the novelty of this venture will last. But hey, if Fondue Fred has survived all these years later, certainly there could be room for Fondue Cowboy. After all, all you have to do is feel...

Like a fondue cowboy
Loungin' out on a bench in a star-spangled halter top
Like a fondue cowboy
Chewin' chunks of bread with skinny people I don't even know
And offers comin' under the stall

FOOD - 4 stars...hard to screw up melted cheese, a few meatballs couldn't have hurt
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...pervasive hipster vibe for a most retro food
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...a little pushy at the beginning but evened out
TOTAL - 4 stars...I'll leave it at 4 stars since I know from the sampler party that the $12 Happy Trails (Dark Chocolate with Cayenne) is totally worth trying
author: Ed U.

description:
In a word: 'meh.'

It's fine. Kinda gimmicky, not very filling. 

I'd just as soon put together a cheese plate at home and eat the whole thing. It would cost less and taste more interesting.

The whole place feels like it's trying way too hard to be this bizarre image (strongly flavored cheese dip and cowboys). It just doesn't hold together.
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Fondue Cowboy, what an interesting name...

I surprised my boyfriend by taking him here for our anniversary.  He was trying to guess where I'm was going to take him all day! The clue I gave him was 'cowboy', and he thought we were going to a steakhouse!  Needless to say, he was curiously occupied until we reached our destination. 

We ordered the 'Outlaw', which was a melody of cheddar cheese, jalapenos, roasted tomatoes, and etc.. I was expecting sharp, tangy cheddar cheese flavor with a hint of spiciness from the jalapenos, but I could hardly taste any of the ingredients. The fondue was mediocre... I've definitely had better.  We ordered a plate of sausages to go with the fondue and it was the best decision ever!! The plate of sausages were spicy hot link sausages and my-oh-my was that delish!!

My 4-star rating is not for the fondue, but rather the salads + spicy hot links!  This is probably the best beets salad I have ever had and my boyfriend loved his pear salad!  They were yellow beets and they had a hint of sweetness in them that complimented the bitterness of the greens.  The pears on the pear salad have been poached in wine and they tasted amazing.

I would definitely go again and give the fondue another shot.
author: Colleen L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night. The interior was cozy and small, but did not have any kind of "cowboy" feel going on minus the western movie playing in the background. The moment I walked in, a server delightfully greeted me. The service here is fantastic and the servers are very helpful and friendly.

We ordered the Outlaw (savory fondue) and Happy trails (sweet fondue). I had high expectations for the Outlaw, but I was left extremely disappointed. For a cheese fondue, I couldn't taste any cheese! The alcohol was way too strong and overpowering. Anything and everything that touched the fondue tasted like alcohol. However, I did enjoy the dippers separately, especially the mini pickles.

Thankfully, the Happy trails fondue was not too bad. I was pleasantly surprised by the addition of cayenne to the dark chocolate, but it was also a little overpowering near the end. My favorite dippers were the bananas, strawberries, marshmallows, and kiwis. The madeleines were very dry. Even though the dessert was good, I could have made my own chocolate covered fruit at home for cheaper.

The Outlaw - 1 star
Happy Trails - 3 stars
Service - 5 stars
author: Monica L.

description:
My boyfriend and I have had dinner there 3 times and love it! 

Their fondues are really good and I especially like the delicious bits of fresh cut apes and brocolli and sauteed potatoes and other lovely bites that are served with to dip in. 

The 3 salads that they offer are consistently top notch, fresh seasonal ingredients perfectly dressed and presented. They also have a charcuterie plate and have 3 types of desert fondue. I wish they had more salads and other vegetable dishes, they are just so good. The folks there are super friendly and service is great. They serve wine on tap which is environmentally friendly and the ambiance is fun. 

I would love it if they played more underground/rarely shown/classic cowboy movies than the super famous ones they play, and I would love to see more non fondue dishes on the menu, as all their sides seem so promissing. 

Best place to get a fondue in the city for sure! Go check it out!

Check some of the beautiful photos of their dishes that I posted.
author: Maxime P.

description:
Good thing I made a reservation for Friday night, because shortly after being seated, the place gets swarmed. I always liked the ambiance of this place (it's my second time here). The restaurant is definitely on the small side, but I thought it's really cute. Nice,subtle touch on the "cowboy/western" decor--not too overwhelming. I find the cowboy clips they play on the TV really amusing as it ran on a replay so it kept on playing. I don't mind it at all as I love horses and the vintage cowboys. 

Service was great for us that night. Our server was really attentive even after the place got busier. We took time with our fondue and meat plate, and she didn't take the chance to rush us at all. 

As for the fondue, we thought it was quite tasty, however we felt that it had a little too much wine content in it, making the cheese a little on the bitter side (perhaps not bitter per se, but in a sense of alcohol content). I might ask them to add little wine the next time I order. It's totally not their fault--some people like it likewise. For dessert, we went for the white chocolate fondue with fruits. Oh boy, weren't we a little too full!
author: Rika P.

description:
I went here on a Saturday evening with a reservation, but the place wasn't as busy as I'd expected. I'd made a reservation anyway. It's also in a slightly suspect part of town, so the walk up isn't exactly romantic. The decor and interior are appropriate with a classy western theme, although the TV playing John Wayne movies was a little too modern of a touch.

Now for the food: The portions are tiny (and that's being generous). I started with The Quick Draw savory fondue (Manchego, White Wine, Roasted Red Pepper Puree, Roasted Garlic). On paper, it sounds delectable. In my mouth, it was horrible. The salt overdose singed my tongue. They weren't particularly selective with their dipping pairings either: it's a standard set of sides no matter what cheese you order. The fondue might have been better had they pureed sweeter red peppers and blended them in to offset the saltiness, but at this point the entire thing is a lost cause.

The sweet fondue, though, was a completely different story. I had the Happy Trails (Dark Chocolate with Cayenne). That was AMAZING. The dark chocolate was textured with cacao powder, was not too sweet and the cayenne gave it this impressive spicy kick that stayed with me andkept me coming back for more!

At the end of the day, you can have more well thought out savory fondue almost anywhere else, but if you don't have a choice and have to stop here, then the dark chocolate makes the stop worth it!
author: Vishal A.

description:
My boyfriend is a cheese and fondue lover, so what better place to take him for his birthday than Fondue Cowboy?

I had never been here, but was sold on the Happy Trails (dark chocolate with cayenne pepper). When we arrived, we were warmly greeted by the bartender/server and he directed us to our cozy spot. 

To start off, we ordered 2 glasses of wine and decided the best cheese fondue to try was The Outlaw (Aged Cheddar, Beer, Slow Roasted Tomatoes, Roasted Garlic, Roasted Jalapeno, Cilantro). YUM! We even ordered a sausage platter. which to my understanding changes daily. The day we went they were serving up Louisiana hot links, which were deliciously spicy. I loved the dippers that came with the cheese- bread, seasoned potatoes, mini pickles, greek olives, etc. The pot looked small, but surprisingly was enough for all the dippers and sausage platter we ordered.

We ordered a variety of cocktail drinks, which were unique since the main alcohol component was wine and not hard liquor. I wish I could remember some of the drinks, but by this point I was too drunk :).

Surprisingly, we did not order the Happy Trails and stuck to a traditional milk chocolate fondue with walnuts (the Buck-A-Roo). Another YUMMY treat.

Total damage= $98.55 (OUCH! Damn all that alcohol...but completely worth it. FYI: More than half the damage is attributed to the alcohol, so don't be hesitant to try this place!)

Also considering the intimate setting of the restaurant I would not go here with more than 1 or 2 friends or on a date (the space is very small). Definitely worth a try!
author: Surge C.

description:
Dined at Fondue Cowboy about two weeks ago with one of my best buds. We walked in around 6:30pm on Saturday night without dinner reservations, so we were seated at the bar which was cool. The restaurant's look is sleek and modern - very nice. They had a flat screen at the bar that played old Western movies; that was kind of weird but I guess it fit into the "cowboy" theme. 

This was my first time ever having fondue so we asked the waiter for his recommendation. He said the Quick Draw was his favorite so that's what we ordered! When it came, it was a pretty small pot of melty goodness accompanied by grapes, apples, bread, olives, pickles, and potatoes. The cheese was okay, but I would probably try something different next time. We both ordered 1 glass of wine each, then proceeded to gossip about everything under the sun. 

The bill came out to be around $40. We didn't order much so I thought it was kinda pricey, but I guess all fondue restaurants are on the expensive side. I'm glad that I got to experience fondue, but I'm not sure I would be so quick to come back. 

Overall I had a good time, the service was good, and the food was OK. I'd go back because I like the vibe of the place and I'd still like to try the sweet fondues!
author: Krystle I.

description: The Outlaw fondue is tasty. The restaurant is small and they book seatings so that you have a limited, allotted time to eat. (Its not one of those restaurants you can sit at for 3 hours, eating and drinking all night long). The service was so-so. Beware if you have large bills, because our server struggled to get change when our party paid with $100 bills. Overall it was somewhere between OK and good.
author: Jenny G.

description:
I'm kind of obsessed. First, the concept: It fulfills all your fantasies about San Francisco and more. I had a friend join us for dinner here immediately coming off the plane and he was amused beyond belief. And now, onto the food.

Yes, the servings are a bit small, but the five of us shared three fondues (the original, the outlaw and the one with mushrooms ... can't remember the name), plus a couple plates of potatoes and bread, pickles, broccoli, olives, grapes and apples. Hands down, the crowd favorite was the one with mushrooms, but we enjoyed all of them. I had never before dipped a gherkin into a vat of cheese but I was an instant convert. 

It came out to only $15 per person but we arrived around 5:45pm to make it for the happy hour prices. Such a fantastic deal!! This includes draft beer and white wine too. Our waiter was also super accommodating and friendly. 

I take off one star because we were limited to having the table for one hour (apparently other parties were on their way), which was a pity as we would've liked to sit and schmooze longer, but I suppose Fondue Cowboy can't help it if they're loved!
author: Tiffany W.

description: Yeah, this place is friendly and great food quality. Price is ambitious, but apparently the market doesn't compete much. I'd definitely come back. It's a great, dark hideaway for friends or a special occasion.
author: Joseph R.

description: I have to say that, as someone who loves the crap out of cheese and chocolate, this should have been an easy sell for me.  But it just wasn't that flavorful.  There's a way to make even "plain" fondu really complex flavor-wise, and this wasn't it.  And the "cowboy" fondue (that was supposed to have all these great flavors/spices) wasn't really any more flavorful.  Do I love dipping shit in melted cheese?  Yes, yes I do.  But I like it more when it feels like something I couldn't just do at home.  Also ,the chocolate was good, of course (it's melted chocolate), but, again, just not that great.
author: Tarah D.

description: Happy Hour is 5pm-6pm. 50% off cheese fondue ($12ish) and chocolate ($10ish) and draft beers. Everything was delish and super fun. Very pricey for what it is, but worth it during happy hour for sure. Enjoy!
author: Amber M.

description: This place is AWESOME and they deserve all 5 stars! We came here for a company dinner of 16 people and from the service/food we all enjoyed every minute of it! We will be back very soon!!
author: Benz H. B.

description:
Shame on you Fondue Cowboy.

A string of unlucky events...I lose my vision at the Lasik center.  Therefore I give a homeless man $10 instead of one as I exit 5th street.  He says God Bless you, I say Gesundheit. Now I'm hearing things or maybe not.  
  
"We've received uncanny news of a Chocolate Meltdown!" and I repeat...

How does a fondue house run out of CHOCOLATE at 8:15pm on a Tuesday?!!  Imagine it be a Friday, your crowd of good looking 20-30 something year olds would have KRON 4 and 7 on Your Side beeline to investigate.  

Jack in the Box has 100 + items on their menu, open 24 hrs a day, and manages to pull off a teriyaki bowl to a poor yap in Detroit.
Fondue Cowboy has three items on their menu: Chocolate, White Chocolate, and Cheese.  It's pretty hard to fxck that up.

Keep on hustling if you want your business to stay afloat.  You don't tell a customer you ran out of chocolate!  Think "What Would Clint Eastwood do?" Giddyup to Ghirardelli Square and buy a 50lb bar!  Unreasonable? Then mosey on over to the liquor store and yank the whole aisle clean. Buy a quick pick while ur at it.  A good business man improvises.
   
I give Fondue Cowboy three stars for the items we did order and enjoy: The Quickdraw, Stagecoach, and White Chocolate fondue. The Tab was $20 each for a party of three.   

Since I wasn't allowed to wear makeup after my eye surgery, I tried to deflect the situation with my mustache.  See our pics in the gallery, it's kinda hard to miss...
author: Jenny G.

description:
Eh, I'm glad I tried this place, but I have no plans/desire to return. 

Overall, it was ok.  The service was good, and I liked the wine selection.   I also liked the set up of the restaurant, with the variety of bar, chair and booth seating.  We came in the middle of the week, so it was slow and got the table right in front with the window.

We got two savories and one sweet fondue.  I enjoyed the variety of dippings, but the fondue was just ok.  We shared the outlaw and  rawhide, blah.  The dessert was good, but not memorable either. 

It's decent, but I think Fondue Cowboy really needs to step up their game.  I think we ended up paying $25-30, which is fine for a night out and hanging out with friends, but I think too much for the quality/taste of food.
author: Laura H.

description:
I have a somewhat mixed reaction to this place. The restaurant itself is pretty nice and the people working there were all accommodating and friendly as well. The price is not bad considering you can get 2 different fondues for $50 total and it will feed 4 people fairly well. I think the downside is that there is only so many pieces of potato, bread or veggie that you can dip into a cheese sauce before it gets a little boring and one-note. No matter what you dip in the main flavor is cheese, which I love, but it is a bit much. I just might not be a fan of fondue?!

We tried the classic (pretty good) and the manchego (much better). I would recommend getting a side of sausage or beef to add to the items they supply. Honestly, by far the best thing about the meal was the desert. It's hard not to love dipping fruits, brownie bits and marshmallows into warm chocolate.

Overall a good experience but a one-time visit place for sure.
author: Frank J.

description:
I went to this place for dinner with a group of friends, and this place serves family style, which as an Asian, I LOVE. I unashamedly admit that I am a very picky cheese eater, so when my friends ordered the outlaw fondue (it's got aged cheddar, beer, and roasted tomatoes and more inside) to start us off, I was hella skeptical. The number of cheeses I can eat alone without making a disgusted face is very small, like single-digits-less-than-5 small. Not to mention this was my first time eating fondue too.

So when I actually tried this stuff with some bread I was like HOLEY MOTHER OF POOP I HAVE BEEN MISSING OUT CAUSE THIS SHIT IS BOMB AF. Granted the beer flavor was strong (and I'm personally not a fan of beer) but DAYUMMM this shit was great anyway. Plus all the little dippers that came along with it, including our cured meat platter with prosciutto and salamis, were really yummy. 

And next came the happy trails fondue, which had dark chocolate and a dash of cayenne that really brought out an awesome heat to the fondue. The little dipper fruits were so fresh and sweet, and you could feel the kick from the hint of cayenne at the back of your throat, which felt great and added a new dimension of flavor to the fondue.

Both fondues overall were really flavorful and had a great smooth and thick consistency to it. Not to mention this meal was well worth the price too! I would definitely come here again.
author: Sarah B.

description: Really yummy, and the prices were okay. I definitely wish they had brownies with the dessert fondue, instead of the chocolate bread or whatever it was. We went on a Wednesday at 730, and we were practically the only ones there.
author: Emily D.

description: Was there for a friends birthday dinner on 6/5/15. The restaurant is small but very cute. The menu and decor is cowboy themed so it was fun to dress up. It's different than The Melting Pot because you do not need to cook anything, which I really liked. I think it's a bit strange that at a place like The Melting Pot you have to cook your own chicken and beef. All the cheeses were very tasty and the staff was very friendly. Looking forward to going back another time, hopefully on a date:)
author: Danielle D.

description: Great service and tasteful food. Fun drinks all of them wine based. The place is so comfortable and beautiful
author: Adriano R.

description: Terrific!  We were a party of three, and ordered the traditional and rawhide, as well as the cured meats tray. It was all delishious!  Honestly, we should have ordered three fondues-they suggest that one fondue serves 2, but I think I had more than my fair share, so 3 would have been better for our cheese-loving party!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
My boyfriend is a huge fondue fiend, and although I'm not as big a fan, I do love cheese.

The decor was great - low lighting (perfect for a date night), western themes walls and a western film playing in the background behind the huge bar. The waiters were very friendly and we got great service (although we were sitting at the bar to be completely honest).

We decided to order the pear and Gorgonzola salad as a starter to share, the cheddar beer fondue with a sausage ate for dips. The salad was delicious and a generous portion. The fondue came with loads of dips in addition to the sausage dip we ordered - bread, potatoes, veggies and fruit. It's a great deal considering the price of the fondue. I also got a mojito and it was delicioussss although I'd love to try the strawberry mojito because this is made with white wine which sounds very interesting. 

All in all we had a delicious dinner experience and will definitely be coming back. I highly recommend this restaurant :)
author: Alice W.

description: Yum yum yum! Their cheeses are delicious and there is a wide variety of items to dip. The servings are perfect for two to share. It is a very small intimate setting but the quality of ingredients is wonderful.
author: Tory C.

description: What a rip off! I came here because I love cheese, and well...the place serves fondue, but the menu is pretty limiting otherwise. Besides fondues, there are three salads to choose from, and that's pretty much it.  I ordered two savory fondues: the rawhide, which had gorgonzola, emmenthaler, white wine, bacon, roasted garlic. Followed by the Outlaw: aged cheddar, beer, slow roasted tomatoes, roasted garlic, roasted jalapeño and cilantro. Despite the interesting list of ingredients in each fondue, I couldn't really taste anything beyond the garlic and the chili. Their portions were tiny, the size of appetizers. After two fondues, a shared salad, and a glass of wine each, my friend and I left "dinner" feeling rather hungry, and out almost a hundred dollars. I came home disappointed, so I made a burrito to satisfy my appetite.
author: Juan F.

description:
This place is so very good... The only other fondue I have had in the city was at Melt (north beach) and that was pretty horrible; they have like a 5-6 star difference in quality.

The entree fondues came with pieces of bread, vegetarians and mini baked potatoes.. The potatoes were really yummy, and the fondues were both really good.

For dessert, we had the white chocolate, a milk chocolate and a dark chocolate fondues.. The dark chocolate is supposed to be famous here, but that was the least popular one our table! The white chocolate one was delish.. the sponge cake pieces and fruits they gave us for dipping complimented that one the best.

This is a great find.. definitely need to come back here again!
author: Aditya M.

description: Id definitely go back here! Since we were 4 people we got the outlaw and quick draw - I preferred the spicy kick of the outlaw. We also got the beet salad (too few beets!), meatballs and the sausage - meatballs were really good! We also got the dark chocolate fondue.
author: Nika M.

description: My friends and I came in a few Saturdays ago for a girls' night out.  We had been out all day and had to push our reservation back from 7:00 to 8:30.  The staff we spoke with over the phone was very accommodating and held our table, even though they appeared to be full, or close to that evening.  We ordered two salads, the Outlaw and two other fondues (Outlaw was the biggest hit which is why I remember the name right off).  Food was AWESOME.  And chocolate fondue was to die for.  We were there for hours, and after a few rounds got louder and louder.  Yikes.  But everyone who attended to us was gracious and helpful until we stumbled out with full bellies super late.  I saw the restaurant lights go out as our uber pulled away.  Appreciate the first class service from beginning to end.  Will be back!
author: Erica H.

description:
My main issue with Fondue Cowboy was the menu! This place would be much better positioned as a type of starters & desserts place.... but I just didn't feel like there was a valid "main course" option. Eating heavy cheese (with the yummy dippings) and sausage for dinner did NOT make me feel well.

That being said, the cheese & chocolate were both tasty. I just definitely won't come back for dinner.

I wish they had a broth / meat option (or even just a chance to order a grilled chicken breast or something?!)
author: K. D.

description:
It's a good place for fondue -- we've tried a few different menu offerings, and our favorite is the Outlaw. 

The ambiance is nice and romantic, and the staff is friendly and helpful. What I didn't quite like was the construction work on the street, and parking wasn't the best. 

All in, pretty decent!
author: Kevin N.

description:
Well, please note that we are cheese fondue junkies, have enjoyed them all over Switzerland and seek them out when traveling. That said, I was excited to try Fondue Cowboy. I would give it 4 stars for creativity and taste, but 3 stars for portion sizes and price. You don't partake in a cheese fondue experience to skimp or to leave hungry.

Three of us ordered two Traditional fondues, salads and the Happy Trails dark chocolate cayenne for dessert. Total bill over $100. The quality was good, just not enough.

We did enjoy the Gruyere/Emmenthaler mix, the potatoes, and the cornichon pickles. They were authentic. 

Don't get me wrong, this place is 1000% better than a Melting Pot. I guess we are just spoiled by the real thing.
author: Stephen H.

description:
So disappointing.  I've had a fair amount of fondue in my day, including in Switzerland, at Matterhorn on Van Ness, and routinely at Melting Pot.  This, my friends, was none of the above.  The options are severely limited (just a few kinds of cheese, a couple salads, and three chocolate options).  The portions were small (something a lot of the yelp reviewers seem to agree with).  There's no "entree" option, where one can do steak/chicken/veggies in a broth/oil/wine, which is always one of my favorite parts.  

To start, we got the Traditional, which should have been amazing (we even asked for extra garlic!).  It was not amazing.  It was bland (possibly they believe it to be a "subtle" flavor profile?) and completely lacking in flavor.  We actually asked for more salt (which did help).  The dipping options were fine/standard fare, and were abundant.  Even with the small portion, we didn't finish because we were so disappointed.  We skipped the chocolate because we didn't want to be disappointed again.  While we had planned to gorge ourselves on cheeses and chocolate until bursting, we just finished off our wine and planned to finish up dinner at another restaurant instead.  

On the plus side, the service was great, our waiter was very friendly and attentive, and the Dry Creek Sauv Blanc was delish.

In the future, when I want cheesy goodness, I'll stick to those tried and true places instead.
author: Nicole J.

description:
As we sat at the bar at Fondue Cowboy, 3 hrs before my cousin had to head back to NYC, we came up with a small joke, saying that, this cowboy needed to saddle up, or be ready to get himself back to Texas... 

We got the traditional because the thought of a bowl of liquid gruyere just made our hearts sing... Sadly, it never hit the notes we were expecting it to... Never having had fondue before, we have nothing to match it to, but we were expecting an awesome cheesy kick in the mouth! Like, cover my mouth with melted cheese deliciousness! Instead, it tasted like it was highly toned down in flavor... Too subtle... 

The dipping options were cool, but seemed a bit lacking... Why not do a little something more flavorful/fun then just bread you've cut up? Or grapes/apples/olives you've piled together?

Perhaps this fondue just needs sometime to find it's bearings... I'm cool with that... But for now, I have a neutral feeling about fondue in general... I hope not all fondue is like this :(

Also --- we joked perhaps this was Cowgirl Creamery's Husband trying to achieve his wife's level... And then we nodded our heads in disapproval --- Cowgirl Creamery is way too cool for that...
author: Mike V.

description: We had a great experience. They were patient with us when we were late for our reservation, gave great service throughout, and the food was delicious (First fondue, so it's not a very valuable opinion but I really liked the food), especially the milk chocolate!
author: Felipe C.

description:
The service was great.
The fondue didn't taste like French Cheese Fondue though :-(
author: Leslie P.

description: This place is awesome. My girlfriend is allergic to garlic (and a ton of other stuff) and they totally tailored our dinner around her allergies. Totally amazing, attentive and delicious. We're coming back.
author: Jesse S.

description:
We were pleasantly surprised that there is happy hour at 5PM on Sunday and was able to sit at the bar which offers half off the savory and chocolate fondue. The portions were much smaller than I expected (but the only other restaurant fondue experience I had was Melting Pot). It was an early dinner and my friend and I weren't that hungry, but had we wanted a full dinner, we would have had to order more.

Savory fondue: Outlaw: the bartender said this was their most popular flavor, the pot is very small and the dipping ingredients are: bread, potatoes (by far the best thing we had), pickles, olives, grapes, broccoli, slices of green apples.

Sweet fondue: Buck-A-Roo (milk chocolate): the chocolate wasn't too sweet, which was appreciated and it's in the same size little pot as the cheese fondue, it's kept warm by a small candle at the bottom, which toward the end started burning the chocolate, so wasn't so great. Dipping ingredients included Madeleines, chocolate bread, strawberries, kiwis, peppermint marshmallows, and pineapple. The fruit wasn't too bad, could have passed on the bread.

Overall, I would recommend going for the happy hour, but wouldn't pay full price for the fondues. Just too small of a portion and the flavor was just all right
author: Linda J.

description:
The Bf and I were really excited to try fondue cowboy as we desperately miss our cheese recipes from france.
Let's make it chronologically:
 
Sangria unfortunately needed more wine and less water.  
The mixed green salad. Good size, good flavors, wish there were more pears. 
The 'traditional' fondue. Uh sorry no not really traditional.. This was NOT what you can call a 'real' fondue. It lacked in flavors, in cheese, and in 'good-size value' (portions are so small, plan on tacking a few side plates..)
Bf also has the cured meat plate which apparently was ok.  

Desert, by far the best moment of the dinner. We ordered the milk chocolate and walnut fondue. Delicious! It almost tasted like melted Nutella, yumm!  

I ll give this place credit for the sides they give with the different fondues. The choice of fresh and tasty fruits for the chocolate fondue was just great. 

Service was ok. Our waiter was nice, however I found intriguing that the other waiter that looked more like a manager, did not bother tacking care of us not even once. (Maybe because I work part time as a waitress I take service too seriously, but I won't leave my coworker's table hanging 20min with their empty plates on the table while he is busy somewhere else). Also noted that he did not bother look over his BB/iphone to say 'bye' or 'thank you'  when we passed him on our way out. (yeah ok I love my customers and would run out after them if they did not see me wave bye and say 'merci'...) 

Overall, do not go if you want to experience the taste of a traditional fondue. Do go if you want to alter the chinese, thai, sushi, pizza routine. 

Next is the Matterhorn Swiss.. will see.. But please can someone open a real swiss chalet with raclette, real fondue savoyarde and fondue bourguignonne. Thanks
author: Alice G.

description: great service.  fun ambiance.  great fondue...great flavors.  all food was fresh and tasty.
author: aimee r.

description:
The first time I came here, it was on a date and I had a Groupon. There was a friendly hostess, we had (but didn't need) reservations and were seated and served by an efficient and friendly server. That experience was four stars.

Last Friday's experience was a a downgrade. Gone was the friendly server girl, replaced by a snippy, too-cool-for-school server that shoved us at the bar, even though there were seats.  The other guy at the bar, a little younger but far friendlier, was a little better though he let our empty drink glasses sit empty though we had been trying to catch his eye for 15 minutes.  

Fondue really is overpriced for what it is--melted cheese with small bits of bread and fruit.  This place is no exception. 2 fondue courses, 4 drinks for 2 people came to just shy of $100.00.  The fondue is good, but not that good and the service needs a definite upgrade.  

It's a novel place, and perfect for a date, but I won't come back unless I am craving fondue and my date it paying. Ha!
author: MakeUp M.

description:
Forgive, but don't forget.

I certainly did not forget my first experience at Fondue Cowboy, when we were ignored by the waitstaff for about 10 minutes.  I had no intention of paying full price for anything, so when I saw the Living Social deal, I jumped on it and finally got the chance to go this past weekend.

Thanks to Open Table, they now take reservations (smart).  Around 4 PM on Saturday, I was able to snag us a table for two at 7 PM the same evening, and we were seated almost immediately, as the previous party was leaving at that moment.

We decided to go with the Outlaw (Aged Cheddar, Beer, Slow Roasted Tomatoes, Roasted Garlic, Roasted Jalapeno, Cilantro) and the cured meat plate ($16), which had proscuitto, melons, coppa and sopressata.  Unfortunately they were really thinly-sliced, so I think that it would've been better for dipping had the meat been thicker slices.

The flavor of the cheese was excellent, but the consistency was really off, like it was too thick.  Everything we tried to dip in it came out naked, because the cheese would just slide off.  I also wasn't a fan of the large number of dippers - bread, potatoes, pickles, olives, broccoli, grapes, and apples.  I would've preferred to have more bread; the amount they gave us was barely enough for just myself.

For dessert, we went for the dark chocolate with cayenne.  I'm not a fan of cayenne-anything for dessert, but unfortunately they only had two types of sweet, besides the one we ordered: milk chocolate with walnuts, and white chocolate with strawberry-balsamic puree.  This was recommended, and while it wasn't bad because it wasn't overly sweet, the cayenne gave it sort of an uncomfortable kick in the back of my throat.  Dippers included strawberries, kiwis, bananas, pineapples, and a tray of marshmallows, brownies and madeleines.

Sadly, for the price, portion, and quality, I must say that I prefer The Melting Pot.  Even though service was great that night, it's a really small restaurant so it was sort of loud, and that doesn't lend itself to a romantic ambiance (and fondue is certainly a sort of romantic thing).  Thankfully I had the Living Social deal, and thankfully there was easy street parking, otherwise I would've left pretty pissed.
author: Tori S.

description:
Met some friend who were visiting from down south in the city after a conference.  We were looking for a place out of the way that sounded fun...Fondue Cowboy sounds like a super fun place and who doesn't like fondue!  

We walked from the hotel, I wouldn't suggest it.  Next time, we'll definitely drive or take a cab.  We had to walk through a not so good area to get there.

We ordered The Outlaw, The Stage Coach, The Rawhide and The Quick Draw.  They were all great.  6 girls went to down on some fondue and at the end, we were all STUFFED and there was fondue left over, definitely good portions.  

I would eat here again and have a hard time not ordering 4 different fondues.
author: Stacey W.

description:
Ok. I don't like giving bad reviews, it makes me feel bad but this place is not worth your time.

Two things were bad about our experience, the food and the service. 

We went for my birthday, my fiance made a reservation, and we were seated prompt-ish. It's a small place, but there was literally one other table with patrons (that should have been a clue on a Friday night, but it was early, so, yeah, right?) and we still waited a couple of minutes. Service -1.

I had the fondue and fiance had a salad which he liked. The fondue was terrible, I like to eat and I took three bites of it and I was done. I actually had a little kid moment where I said to myself "I am not putting one more bite into my mouth!!!"  Food -1.

About 20 minutes after the food was delivered it was obvious it had barely been touched, and our waiter came over to check, we let him know it was no kind of good.. He did offer to get us another to try, but seeing how their service was thus far, I was sure we'd get the bill for both and the second would be just as awful. Service -2

I'm used to decent service, if it's in a dive or if it's in a 5 star restaurant, generally if you don't like something, they fix it, make it better, or at the least don't charge you and apologize. We did get an offer for something else. Service -3

We had been looking forward to the chocolate fondue, but it was a no-go at this point. We did eat the apples, grapes, and sirloin steak plate. 

I did have a drink that was tasty, a lychee martini, which is a super sweet fruit. 

The bill came and it was full on everything, and no apology. Service -4
author: Paula S.

description:
Why not just either tell people that they want you out fast when you make the reservation (so we can choose if that's the right place for our occasion), or use the standard open table estimates for diners?
We were all pretty appalled at our experience last night.  

They took the fondue before we were done and brought the check before we could order dessert (we did anyway).  Too bad for them, one of our party works at a nearby hotel and will definitely not be recommending this restaurant.  Good luck staying in business.  The food's not even that unique.  combine that with being a crappy proprietor and your business will go under soon.
Never coming back here again.   

Nice waiter - he should work somewhere else cause I'm sure he's losing a lot in tips because his boss sucks.
author: Dan S.

description: Food was good but bit pricy for melted cheese and raw vegetable and fruits.
author: Anna Y.

description:
Came in here with some friends and had such a great time. We love us some fondue especially the Outlaw!. We had a chocolate fondue that had some kick to it...not sure it was cayenne pepper or what but it was awesome and was a big hit.

We sat at the bar waiting for a table but ended up staying there the whole time and got to meet the owner who was a really nice guy. Will go back for sure!
author: Teo B.

description:
I just went here with another couple and we definitely enjoyed the evening. The waitstaff were pleasant and the food was really good. We ordered the Stagecoach and the Quickdraw for cheese with the meat plate. We also ordered the bean salad and the beet salad. Finally, we topped off our meal with the dark chocolate fondue. All said, the food was very good. The salads were good sized portions. The cheese fondue came with roasted potatoes, fresh bread, apple slices, broccoli, olive, pickles, and grapes. The chocolate came with strawberries, bananas, kiwi, pineapple, chocolate bread, pound cake, and home made marshmellows. 

The only reason I'm giving a 3 star review is that I do think they need to add more options to the menu.  While I LOVE cheese,  a little more protein on the menu would have been appreciated. The food was good, but it wasn't as satisfying a meal as I would have liked. I wish they had a few more apps or entree options.  

Overall, I would go back...maybe next time they'll have a couple more options on the menu!
author: Anne D.

description:
Thought about giving this place 3 stars, but "Meh, I've experienced better" pretty much sums this place up.  

My girlfriend is a fondue fan, so I picked FC to try for a birthday dinner.  Fondue is really a no brainier, and for the price, FC should really be delivering something a little more special than what they are putting out there.

Drinks:

I got a goose Island Matilda.  GF got a glass of champagne.

Salads:

Beet salad and Mixed Greens.  tasted like something I'd get form MIXT greens.  Nothing special.  The mixed greens salad did have a lot of bacon in it, so good for you if you like a ton of bacon.

Fondue: The Rawhide (Italian Dolce Gorgonzola, Emmenthaler, White Wine, Bacon, Roasted Garlic)

Not a ton of Gorgonzola flavor and to much wine.  Not bad, but not great.

The real let down was the bunch of really standard dipping items (i.e. raw broccoli that looked like it came off a party tray from safeway, half a green apple cut into inconsistent chunks, sourdough bread).  Or odd dipping items like the olives and pickles that really didn't work.

This is the one chance they have to be really creative and shine, and everything looks cheap and haphazardly thrown together, like they were to lazy to put any thought into what they were serving.  

Dessert: Dark Chocolate with cayenne

I liked the flavor pairing of the dark chocolate and the cayenne pepper, but again the sides were a big let down.  COSTCO BROWNIES? (Yes the little brownie cups from COSTCO)  COSTCO MADELINES?    It's not like I won't recognize that stuff,  Are you even trying?

Overall, this place doesn't pay a lot of attention to the details and in SF in this price range, there is much better out there.
author: Andrew L.

description:
This is not your typical huge pot and tons of bread fondue place.  The portions are petite, about 4 ounces a pot with a large variety of included dippers.  Great place for fondue tapas snacks with draft wine.  The sweet fondue was just the right size, but the savory left me wanting for more.  Many of the dippers remained undipped due to inadequate cheese.

The Outlaw: Pretty soupy for fondue, was difficult getting the cheese to cling to any dipper except the bread.  Tasty but bordered too closely to a nacho dip with the tomatoes, garlic, cilantro and jalapeños.  Would have preferred that they steer towards a cheddar & ale Welsh rarebit since this incarnation of the cheddar was not that sophisticated.

The Stage Coach: AWESOME!  I could have easily ate a gallon of this.  Compte is such a brilliant cheese choice because of it's like the traditional fondue gruyère, but with more personality.  I think there were some well paired mushrooms in it too.  Perfect consistency for any dipper.

Dippers for Savory Fondue: The whole grain bread and roasted small potatoes worked well.  The raw broccoli was a bit overpowering, even when smothered in cheese.  Apples and grapes were provided, not my thing but I suppose others like them.

Cured Meats Platter: Wish they skipped the melons and gave more meat.  Already enough fruit in the standard dipper selection.  The meats were prosciutto and thinly sliced salamis.  The cheese overpowered their subtlety, probably would have been better to have some cooked sausages like chorizo or kielbasa for a meatier side dish. 

Happy Trails: The cayenne had a bit of a kick in the first dip, but faded into the heavy dark chocolate pool afterwards.  Was very creamy for dark chocolate, but kept the bitter cocoa bite.  Seemed more like dark chocolate custard as opposed to melted dark chocolate, perhaps they need to ease up on the half-n-half.

Dippers for Sweet Fondue: The freshly sliced fruit was a win - strawberries, bananas and bing cherries.  The chocolate bread wasn't that chocolaty, which is actually good else it would have been overkill.  I wasn't keen on the regular bread since that's just weird in chocolate.  Wish they had some cookies, angel food cake pieces or brownies for dipping.
author: Adam B.

description:
Great food!! Service staff amazing. 

Recommend: any of the salads (tried all three), the cheese fondue's were delish, tried two of 'em - I don't think you can go wrong with any of them.

Drinks: get the lychee martini, it's sweet, but a great balance for the savory of the fondue. The sangria was good, but standard, not as good as the lychee.

Dessert: you're thinking about it, well, stop thinking about it, just get it, you don't have a fondue pot at home, and you don't have chocolate bread. Yes, chocolate bread, the chocolate fondue (had the white choco) comes with a large portion of fixings: different fruits (kiwi, bananas, strawberries, etc.) and chocolate bread, marshmallows, etc. it's a sharing thing, we split one dessert fondue between 5 of us. 

The space is small and intimate, so you might have to hang at the bar for a bit before getting a table, but 5-6 is happy hour.
author: Kalpesh J.

description: I love fondue, visit Switzerland almost every year & a true favourite, so I was very excited to find a funky little indie Fondue place on a recent trip to SF. It didn't dissapoint, I'll admit I've had better Fondue from the Swiss, but this was a really good take on it, with nice veg dipping options. The menu was perfectly placed in its simplicity. Great atmosphere & decor. Would go there for a casual drink anyway. Really enjoyed it. 2 person staff seemed to be running the show & did a great job!
author: Ben M.

description:
We were thrown out! The Cops were called! - read on.....

Date and I decided have an early dinner at Fondue Cowboy, so we made a reservation 6:30, Friday. We were greeted by our waiter who offered us our table next to a few (semi loud) patrons. We asked if instead we could take a two-top in the middle of the very empty restaurant. After a sour look and much deliberation, Waiter said no to our request as that table would be joined to another to make a larger table. Oh well....

Toward the end of our meal, we noticed that the larger table never transpired, and that in fact the table we asked for was occupied by another couple. Both date and I were annoyed and wondered why we were denied the table, so I asked the waiter to explain. Stumbling through his explanation, (I guess frustrated that I challenged him) he asked if I would like to speak to the owner, to which i replied "No. I want to speak with you, but if you want me to speak with the owner, that's fine". 

Owner (Dave Mur?) came over to the table and without any lead-in, said aggressively, "You have a problem with your table? Why don't you just get out of here". Shocked at why we were being treated like this, I tried to explain again,  but the owner continued yelling, and causing a pretty big scene in the middle of a curious and shocked restaurant, ordering us out.

As we were leaving the restaurant, the owner's self-proclaimed boyfriend came over to us yelling about being on the sidewalk in front of the restaurant. I told him I was waiting for my CC receipt. He called the police to have us removed. 

Anyway, cops came, laughed at being called, bid us a good night,  I got my receipt and we left. As we were walking away, the owner's boyfriend started screaming something at my date about having more expensive clothing than she .  The last thing we saw was the two cops that he called, converging on the ranting lad. I wonder if  he got himself arrested as his pupils were so dilated they looked like little Christmas sugar plums.  

Never in my (plenty of) years have i been treated like that from the proprietor of a business. I had worked in the restaurant business for a long time &  I've frequented hundreds of food establishments of all types. I am accommodating sometimes to a fault  to the food and beverage community because I know it's a tough racket being a waiter or bartender. This was an absolute first for me. Distasteful, undeserved & completely degrading experience.

Click on the rating details for this joint and look at the downward trend of the reviews...maybe paints a different picture than their 4 stars imply? 

Shame, cos the food wasn't bad. I guess the moral of the story is don't F*cK  with the seating plan at Fondue Cowboy.
author: David L.

description:
Not sure why the guy on 9/10 is such a complainer. I was there - saw the entire thing. True, he wanted to move to another table. True, Dave could not move them due to a larger reservation. And True, the larger party never showed up (they were a no show)
However, the guy didn't mention that they were almost done with their dinner when the larger party didn't show - so what would be the point of moving them. Also, he didn't mention what appeared to be his "date" giving Dave the finger right in his face. (at least that's what it looked like to me...I could be wrong)
He also didn't mention that his money was refunded.

Is this guy running for political office? Seems he left out all the facts.
Maybe Dave should have told them the party cancelled and given them an option to move - even though their dinner was almost done.
Maybe all involved over reacted - including themselves and Dave.

At any case, I've dined here numerous times - always have great service and always have a great meal - and, besides, this guy also said the food was good.

Just my observation - not a judgement.
author: Peter S.

description:
Hi. 

It was "aight." 

The bf and I were really looking forward to coming here on Friday night, since he was going to take me out to dinner after a rough week. (Probably more me and him).  SCOREZELTON! 

We walk in around 7:55, and got seated promptly at 8pm. Our server came over, and then took our order of drinks. Here is where one star gets knocked off. 

I don't really like sweet drinks. Actually, I don't like them at all! So I asked our server ( a really sweet girl) to make my lychee martini (made with soju) with less syrup. LESS THAN 5 MINUTES later, she comes with our drinks, but the first thing she says is, 
"Oops I forgot you asked for it less sweet. try it anyway and let me know what you think." 

*pucker face* (me) "uhhhhh it's okay?" 
Look, I am not one to confront people. In fact, I don't really care if there is the occasional odd object  in my food. However, if you acknowledged that you messed up, why not just go back and make another one and not put me in an uncomfortable situation? I told her it was "ok," then she smiled and just walked away. .....er.....

OK. Whatever. I'll just wait for the ice to dilute the drink. 

Our beet salad was good, pretty much the highlight of the night. We ordered the spicy cheese fondue with jalapenos, along with a side of sausage. When the fondue came, I had to take another star off. There was no taste whatsoever. We even ordered extra jalapenos, but....ughhh. I did not want to ask for salt cause that would be tacky, but I might as well have been eating some spicy creamy whatever sauce. That made me really sad how completely bland it was.  I am so glad we ordered the sausage (although reminiscent of Costco hot links), because that was the saving grace of the night. 

So overall....it was okay. More like 2 stars, but I can't bring myself to do it.  The server girl was still really nice, but I was just really disappointed in how she handle the martini situation. The bf and I both left pretty unsatisfied, and went to drown his irritation at paying $100 for dinner at Bloodhound. 

Next time I should definitely speak up..but I don't think there will be one.
author: Christina L.

description:
Yummy, yummy, in my tummy! The Outlaw cheese fondue is soooooo delicious! And those crispy salty potatoes! The salads are also really good and great for sharing. My ultimate favorite though is the homemade marshmallows! Good gravy are those delicious!

Love this place!
author: Amanda R.

description: If I could get away with eating fondue here every day I would.  Food is excellent, reasonably priced, and the staff is super nice... Best part of the neighborhood :)
author: Steven J.

description: I went here with my boyfriend and parents for my mom's birthday. We got the Traditional and Stage Coach fondues as well as mixed greens salads and the meat platter. It was fantastic. The cheeses were perfectly melty and flavorful, all the dippables tasted excellent. I was a bit worried about having enough food but I was perfectly full after finishing everything, and they will bring out another tray of things to dip if you need them anyway. We finished with the dark chocolate dessert fondue which was also fantastic! For 4 people and having had a bottle of wine, the price was very reasonable.
author: Lydia S.

description:
Enticed here with a Living Social deal, I was excited to A) head into SF for date night, and B) try a new fondue restaurant.

It's a quaint open restaurant with cowboy themed decor - half the seating at tables and half at the bar.  Reservations definitely recommended (it's small!).  The menu is straight forward - options of salads, cheese fondue, meat or sausage platter, and chocolate fondue.  

We started by sharing a MIXED GREEN SALAD ($8), then opted for the STAGE COACH fondue ($24).  I have to say, I was surprised by how little food came to the table.  It was a --tiny-- cheese fondue as compared to most places, and just enough for 2 people (that's including the greens and meat).  The cheese fondue had good flavor with mushrooms adding a nice richness to the cheese.  The dippers were eh, and included a lot of filling carbs - bread, both regular and toasted, potatoes, apples, broccoli, pickles, and olives.  We also ordered a CURED MEAT PLATTER ($16), which was a spicy tasty selection of 3 thinly sliced meats with honeydew and cantaloupe.  Thank goodness we had the salad and the meat to go with all that cheese dipped bread.  

We opted to not get a chocolate fondue for dessert, as it would be an additional $16 to an already expensive meal, given what it was.  I'll be heading to La Fondue in Saratoga instead (http://www.yelp.com/biz/la-fondue-saratoga#hrid:htMZqG_Px4T0JkheXZOPwg)....
author: Heather s.

description:
I have eaten here once before and liked it...I spent around $150 for 2 of us.  This is a bit pricey, so I didn't make going here a regular habit.  When I saw a Living Social deal come through, I was super excited & bought one. 

Tonight, I decided to redeem my voucher ($40) and pay the difference for dinner again (most likely another $100).  When I sent onto Living Social, I discovered that someone else had redeemed my voucher!  I called Living Social and waited on hold for about 10 minutes while the nice lady called the restaurant.  She finally came back on the line and told me that the manager, Dave, wouldn't budge and that she can offer me a full refund. Since I wanted the voucher more than the refund, I decided to call him myself.

Dave came to the phone pleasantly enough, but got a little salty as the conversation droned on.  When I told him that this was a regrettable loss of patron to the restaurant, he agreed.  I then went on to try to tell him that all he would have had to do was to comp me an item & life would have been grand.  He cut me off and said, "I am not going to waste any more of my time - I already lost the business anyway."  He then promptly hung up on me.

What a dick!!!
author: Charlene E.

description: Too pricy for fondue. The sausage links was not that great too. The restaurant  was empty too.
author: R P.

description:
I had a meal here with grubwith.us and had a fantastic time!

We started out with pear and gorgonzola salads - a great combination.  Very refreshing, but we were excited for the main event!

We had three different cheeses - the Traditional with gruyere and emmentaler, another with comte (one of my favorite cheese), and the third with a blue cheese.  I'm not the biggest fan of blue cheeses (the gorgonzola and pear salad notwithstanding) so I don't remember exactly which cheese was in that one.  My favorite was the comte but the choice of the table was the blue cheese fondue.  We had a generous assortment of dippables, from the usual bread and roasted potatoes, to the genius broccoli and grapes, to the questionable pickles and olives.

After scraping down the deceptively large crocks of cheese came the two dessert fondues - chocolate with cayenne and white chocolate with strawberry.  Both were fantastic.  They came with assorted fruits and cakes to dip.  My favorite was the kiwi in the white chocolate fondue.

Service was all right - not the best but most everything you needed was at your table already.  The price is right, though, Fondue Cowboy is cheaper than other fondue places I've been (I'm looking at you Melting Pot!).
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Huh?

$25 bucks for a tiny pot of cheese and a small plate of cornichons, olives, bread and an apple?! No proteins (except for the cheese of course, unless you pony up). This place has nothing 'Cowboy' about it. 'Cowboy' in my mind means big food. This is more like an expensive bar-snack and beer joint. The beers are not even served in pints...avoid this.

This place disappoints. If you are looking for a meal, try somewhere else.
author: Tom H.

description: I love fondue, but it's usually ridiculously overpriced. It's cheese and bread, and other than melting the cheese, you do the work. Fondue Cowboy wasn't too overpriced, though, so I would totally go back. I think we had a group of 6 people and our tab was $40/each including 3 pots of fondue and 2 carafes of wine, plus we covered for one girl since it was her birthday and we love her. So, pretty reasonable. Also a super cute interior space.
author: Tasha D.

description:
From reading previous reviews, I wanted to avoid waiting. Thankfully, they now have reservations through opentable. I made a reservation although it probably wasn't necessary for a Thursday.
