The Quick Draw - the red peppers dominated the flavor, came with a LOT of dippers. Bread, potatoes, apples, grapes, olives, pickles...
Meat plate - 3 meats with some cantelope on the side (random!)
Beet salad - I have a slight obsession with beets. This salad had a good amount of golden beets, greens and cheese. yum.
Sangria - fruity but not too sweet.

The decor isn't too "cowboy" they could have played it up a bit more. It's a sleek (but small) space. Super easy parking in this part of the city!
author: Sara P.

description: Great food, portions a perfect size, lovely roasted potatoes, friendly service from sheila and also great value. Definitely coming back
author: Ian V.

description:
Ok sometimes a theme restaurant can be really cheesy.  Oh wait, it's a fondue place, it's supposed to be cheesy!!  The decor is fantastic (but not over the top), from the beautiful floor to the cowboy movies playing on the big screen tv.  It's awesome!  

The food?  Well good but not amazing.  I left feeling really satisfied though.  Incidentally, 3 of us shared a salad, a cheese fondue, and a dessert fondue, and left full.  

I'm really confused about why people are all saying they've spent over $100 here.  Or why they spent that and left hungry.  We are three big eaters and we had plenty.  Our check, even if you add the $20 we saved with the living social deal, was under $100.

We also had good service.  The staff were all friendly, helpful, and easy going.  They were very accommodating with our changing our reservation and then being late.  

Heehaw, yippee ki yay fondue!
author: Linda L.

description: Fondue Cowboy is an absolutely excellent fondue place near downtown SF. I personally believe fondue as a food in America has become too expensive and over-the-top. This restaurant is great because it is fondue as it should be: laid back and in a casual atmosphere. The staff is friendly, the food is pretty cheap but very good. The restaurant has quite a hipster vibe to it and it's a very comfortable place to be. If I had one criticism of Fondue Cowboy it is that the menu felt a little limited as far as variety goes, but overall I must say 5 stars and worth it completely.
author: Hunter N.

description:
The ambiance was nice, the hostess and wait staff were polite and prompt, but the food didn't really blow me a way. A few notes:
* The cheese fondue we had (The Stagecoach) was fairly "meh." It had slightly more flavor than a normal cheese fondue, but overall it fell fairly flat.
* The sides are fine - a lot of potatoes and bread, an apple or two cut up, and a smattering of broccoli, small pickles, and olives (the last being fairly odd).
* If you are looking for meat fondue, keep in mind this place doesn't have it. Not a reason to pull off a star - more just a warning for people expecting it.

There really isn't anything _terrible_ about this place, but it didn't strike me as particularly delicious. Granted, we didn't have the chocolate dessert, but the cheese was so "meh" as to lead us to not even bother finishing it.
author: Dave L.

description: Fondue was standard - I guess I was expecting more of a burst of flavor but I felt generally things were pretty mild.  It still tasted good nonetheless.  +1 star for the waiter giving us another free plate of veggies when we ran out!
author: Pam S.

description:
I came here early on a Friday evening with a large group of 7. I recommend reservations because it's a small restaurant and it gets packed as the evening progresses. The area surrounding the restaurant is a little shady so watch out for yourself when you're here after dark. When I dined there, there was a crowd of cops outside the restaurant. 

Service was friendly but not intrusive. Our server was nice about fulfilling my special requests and didn't drop in on us too much to the point of getting annoying. 

For my cheese fondue, I went with The Outlaw, which is cheddar cheese. It was delicious and accompanied the food well. They give a reasonable amount of dipping items and it's enough to be shared between 2 people. The amount of dippers they give you is more than you'd get at The Melting Pot. The amount of cheese you get is approximately 1 cupful and it's kept warm by a tealight candle. If you have a huge appetite, I recommend adding the sausage dish. The sausage was very good with the cheese and it has a light spicy kick to it without burning off your taste buds. 

For dessert, I made a special request. I ordered dark chocolate with walnuts, which is basically a combination of the Happy Trails and Buck-a-Roo. Feel free to customize your chocolate fondue because they're very accommodating. I also tried the High Noon, which is white chocolate with balsamic strawberry puree. The High Noon is good if you like your desserts very sweet. The strawberry really complements it well but I didn't taste much balsamic in it. And those tealight candles really work very well for keeping the chocolate warm. When I got to the bottom of the pot, it was scalding hot so be careful not to burn yourself! 

For the check, you're allowed to use a maximum of 3 cards per table so bring cash if you're going with a big group.
author: Nancy C.

description: LOVE IT! This place is so awesome! I came with my friend Janet and we just had a blast talking about life while we were eating our fondue and sippin' on some syzzurp (a refreshing and aromatic glass of Pinot Noir). We ordered the spicy dark chocolate (I think it had Cayenne?) and then we dipped our bread, fruit and marshmallows all in the delicious fondue. It wasn't crowded at all (but then again, it was a Monday or Tuesday night) and it was super romantical. I was just staring into the dreamy eyes of my dear friend as we laughed and chatted all evening. Such a great spot! Can't wait to come back to try the other flavors. It is a little pricey but it's the best! And it's located in SOMA. I just found this place down the street from my house and I ended up moving! Darn SF rent...
author: Leena B.

description:
It is hard *not* to like a place that serves piping-hot bowls of melted cheese and chocolate.

I'll echo some other reviewers in saying this is surprisingly affordable fondue, given what other places charge for a similar setup.

We ordered a variety of cheeses, including aged cheddar and gruyere, with the usual dippers: including apples, bread, potatoes, and more. All tasty and more than enough for a ravenous group of nine gossiping ladies at dinnertime.

We got a bit excited and knocked over a glass of vino. Our server was great, re-filling her glass higher than it was before the spill and being very gracious about our, um, excitement. 

I expected to spend a lot more and I'm sure this is partially why I'm so positive. $24 each for more than enough fondue -- three or four savories, two desserts, and a bottle of wine. I started with a glass of red that ran me about $10.

Great for a date (each fondue order comfortably serves two) and groups alike.
author: Tara R.

description:
I looooooove cheese!  Love it.  Can't live without it. Need it.

My new boy and I stumbled upon this place while walking around the neighborhood.  He had never had fondue before and I wouldn't shut the fuck up about how great it is.  The interior is quite darling.  Very cozy but very hip.  My date opted to sit on the same side of the table as me (gasp! I NEVER allow that but have since been converted) and the waiter didn't bat an eyelash.  

We enjoyed the "Traditional."  It was very tasty and satisfying.  We watched the old John Wayne films they had playing. Our waiter was attentive and uber friendly. It was lovely.

My only criticism of Fondue Cowboy is the price of the actual fondue.  $24?  That's a bit over the top.  Our meal was nearly $70 and we shared fondue and only had three drinks between the two of us.  I'm actually starting to wonder how it ended up being that much...
author: Annie G.

description: Took the family here this evening and we all enjoyed it.  2 pots of cheese and 1 pot of chocolate was perfect for our family of 5 (kids 13 down to 6).  We enjoyed the traditional and rawhide cheese pots.  Hard to believe I've been working 4 blocks away for 6 years and this is my first time here.
author: Erik S.

description:
Came here the other night with a group of 8 people so we had the chance to try a few different cheese and chocolate fondus.  The flavor of the cheeses were good - nice combination of flavors and good presentation.  If I was rating the restaurant based only on the cheese, I would give it 5 stars.  

Where I was less impressed was in the dipping options.  The standard dipping items provided are pretty basic, mainly chopped up fruit, veggies and bread.  Yes, these are the great with cheese but it looked like something I could have easily prepared at home and in a place that specializes in fondu, I was expecting a little more "wow" factor.    

I would come here again but not with a big group.  Better with 1 or 2 other people for a glass of wine and a cheese fondu.
author: Jessie W.

description:
This place is great! I've had some bad experiences with fondue restaurants that privilege quantity over quality by e.g.  extending the fondue with filler ingredients like water and flour, or by providing cheap bread. This place doesn't do that: the food is very high quality. 

Pros: Great fondue. High-quality sides like good bread, tiny roasted potatoes, flavourful olives, apples and grapes. Good salads. A decent choice of wines by the glass, well-priced. The service is warm and professional.

Cons: The fondue for two is really only enough for one. The space is a tiny bit loud. It's small so you need to reserve, and it won't suit large groups.
author: Susan P.

description:
Excellent fondue place! I came here after a long day of work. I gave them a call beforehand to try to reserve a place. It's full, and has been unavailable for the last two weeks I tried to book a place on opentable. Nevertheless, being stubborn, I decided to try to walk in. It turned out that the bar is first-come-first-served, and we could still order from the full menu at the bar. We ordered the traditional fondue and the salami platter. Both were excellent. The traditional fondue consists only of vegetables and bread, so if you are a meat-lover, be sure to order a side dish. I highly recommend the citrus cooler. It's made of lycee syrup, lemon, sea salt, and white wine. It's especially amazing if you prefer a weaker kind of alcohol and just want something nice to complement the fondue. 

We ended our dinner with the dark chocolate fondue, which is mouth-watering even as I recall it now. Overall, it's a great restaurant with stylish decor and excellent food.
author: Vivien S.

description:
Can we agree that there should be nothing to be confused about fondue?

Well, Fondue Cowboy really confused me. I mean, it's in the name. What do cowboys have to do with fondue? I have never EVER seen a photo of cowboys eating fondue, neither did "Brokeback Mountain" feature any scenes or talk about fondue.

Of course, I make a joke about how they must be under construction. Their floor is a bunch of construction plywood glossed over. Yet, except for the TV playing cowboy films and the name, there is no association with cowboys. Perhaps because it doesn't exist.

I hope Chef Ramsey comes and sets this place straight with the mix-up in one of the Kitchen Nightmares episodes...and not just the name/interior design. The food lacks as well. One of those places you don't go to unless everything else is closed or you have a deal.

The salad we got was 80% fresh leaves, 20% mushy old leaves. The pear was probably taken out of the compost pile. You could taste it. The cheese was the only good thing, but of course, we only got 2 pieces of it.  Frankly, it was disgusting. Top it off with home-made "croutons" you can't bite or you'll chip a tooth!

The fondue was better. But better doesn't mean great, or memorable, or even really good. It was just alright. So-so.

I guess the sangria was the best thing and the Stella I had. 

Our waiter took forever to come, but that's cause she was the only one serving everyone. She was mumbling 100%, but the place is spot clean, hear that germ freaks?

Apparently a place to go hang out with your girlfriends. Of course, all these girls next to us were loud, new to SF, and didn't know better.
author: Alexia R.

description:
Yee-haw, I say! With a capital Yee! :)

On a brisk night in June, I visited Fondue Cowboy with a group of 10 or so women. One of the gals made reservations online and we took up about half of the restaurant with a long table and stools they had set up for us. The decor was warm, dark, and inviting and the space was quiet enough that we weren't screaming to hear each other.

We ordered four types of cheeses, several platters of dippers (mostly bread and potatoes), two sweet chocolate fondues (milk with walnuts and dark with cayenne), and wine for the table. We also had some plates of pickles and olives to compliment. My favorite savory fondue was the Outlaw which is cheddar, beer, roasted tomatoes, roasted garlic, and jalapeno. For sweet fondues, the dark chocolate with cayenne had a bit too much cayenne for my taste, and I preferred the milk.

Although we occupied half the restaurant for several hours the staff never once rushed us (10 chatty women + wine = an all-night gossip-fest).

The damage? Less than $25/pp after tax and tip. That's WITH alcohol, my friends.

There are probably higher-end, better quality fondue restaurants out there, but Fondue Cowboy is super affordable, fun, and terrific for groups. After all, who doesn't like dipping bite-sized morsels into melted cheese and chocolate?
author: Kel S.

description:
As a cheese lover and connoisseur, I'm embarrassed to say that I hadn't made it to Fondue Cowboy until last night, despite it being open for over a year.

But I made it there, and that's the point, right?

It was happenstance that I ended up here as I was supposed to go to Marlowe but as there was a Giants game in SF last night, we opted to avoid that area. Scrambling, I used my handy-dandy Open Table app on my iPhone to search for restaurants in the area that had reservations. Fondue Cowboy showed up and I made the decision to take the plunge.

When we arrived (at 7pm) it was pretty quiet. It's a rather small space with dark interior, a faux straw floor and sleek tables. All that with cowboy movies playing in the background. The menu is fairly simple, a choice of 4-5 cheese fondues, a similar number of chocolate fondues, some salads and meat plates. 

Since their were four of us, we opted for 2 salads and two cheese fondues to share. We got the white bean salad and mixed greens, and the white bean was definitely our favorite. Flavorful with a bit of tan from the picked red onions. The cheese fondues we opted for were the Desperado which had goat cheese and The Outloaw, a cheddar and jalapeno cheese mix. The Desperado was definitely the favorite. More flavorful and went really well with the side dish of cornichons, olives, broccoli and grapes. The Outlaw was good but we expected more of a kick from the jalapenos. It went really well with the bread and potatoes, tho.

For dessert we got the Happy Trails (dark chocolate and cayenne) and Buck-A-Roo (milk chocolate and walnuts) to share. These came with chocolate bread, marshmallows, madeleine cookies, as well as strawberries, bananas, and grapes. They were both delicious, especially the Happy Trails - but super rich. In hindsight, we probably should've only ordered one, but you live and you learn.

I'm so glad I finally came to this place. I've been to La Fondue in Los Gatos, which is great, but super fancy and pricey. I felt that Fondue Cowboy provides great fondue at a reasonable price, and a more casual (but still great) atmosphere. Looking forward to coming again!
author: Melanie N.

description:
I would love to give this a 5 star because the food is fabulous, the setting is wonderful, and the service was top notch but the prices were just too high.  It isn't even that the servings were too small it's just that a set up like this seems like one should be able to come often, especially when one lives so close, but at their prices that's just not doable.  If you just get 1 fondue platter it isn't so bad but when you add everything else... ouch.  At those prices you could go to a fancy joint.

Here's to hoping the prices lower 'cause I would come here a LOT!
author: Eric G.

description: This is my first yelp review but I have to insist that the fondue cowboy is my favorite date restaurant in the Bay Area. They have a wonderful happy hour and both Gruyere and Cheddar fondue are delicious. I am not normally a sweets person but the dark chocolate and  white chocolate balsamic strawberry fondue are heavenly. You should try both at least once.
author: David L.

description:
This restaurant gets no stars!  What a terrible experience.  The portions are not even large enough for an appetizer let alone an entree.  The "fondue" is served in what is the equivelant of a tuna can with a meager & paltry assortment of stale bread cubes, three apple slices and the strangest of all...two gherkin pickles.  The fondue has absolutely no flavour (how is this possible?) and there is nothing else on the menu at all interesting.  We went because I had a Living Social Coupon but we will never go back or ever recommend this place.  

After our "entree" we left (we were not interested trying anything else as it could only be terrible from what we already had and could see from the other tables) and had to go down the street to another restaurant to get not only enough but actual flavorful food to satisfy us for our dinner at Ooma (a much better place!).  

There is no excuse in San Francisco for such poor execution, quality, pricing and service!  Shame on Fondue Cowboy!  Walk a bit farther on, LuLu is just two blocks away and so much better!
author: Katie A.

description:
My partner and I live in the neighborhood (which, btw is AWESOME and not the least bit "suspect") and are big fans of the fondue!  So its great this place is literally a block from us - we've been wanting to try it for a while.

I get home early and suggest we check it out and grab a couple drinks.  Arriving before 5:30, the place was dead.  I'm pretty sure we were the only diners there.  However - its also "Happy Hour" which means fondues and draft beers are HALF OFF at the bar between 5pm and 6pm!  Score!  Our whole bill (Fondue, the meat side, and four beers!) was like $37 (before tip).  We totally weren't expecting that at all and its super cool that they even offer it.  

In addition, the fondue is awesome.  I agree with the person who said it couldn't be considered "traditional" - but that's the point.  They're cowboys!  Rebels!  Their combinations of cheeses, wines and spices was super interesting.  We settled on the Gorgonzola and decided to split the meat side.  The dipping sides that came with the fondue were great too and with the addition of the meat tray it was the perfect sized meal to share.  The service was great too, and within 30 minutes people started to filter in (missing the Happy Hour specials!  Big dummies!)

The decor is nice also. The image of a (muted) black and white John Wayne spaghetti western playing on the tv set against the yellows of the wall was almost artistic.  Its a sweet vibe.

All in all - I dig it
author: Daniel H.

description:
I haven't been here for food yet, but it was a great spot to grab a few drinks! Their mojitos are amazing and made with fresh fruit! The service was great and the bar tenders are very friendly.

I will defiantly be returning to try their fondue!
author: Mike M.

description:
Cute little place to take a date. The place is small so make reservations if you plan on going. 

I'm so glad their fondues are served in small pots, because it was the perfect portion for 2 people. My husband and I had the Outlaw, complemented by tiny pickles, olives, potatoes, raw brocolli, grapes and bread. Melted cheese is something that tastes good the first couple of bites, but after a while it gets really heavy and filling. We wanted to save room for dessert! 

For dessert, we had the white chocolate with strawberry puree and it was DIVINE. The chocolate bread dipper paired with the white chocolate was a match made in heaven. I'm drooling just thinking about it. Some other dippers included fruit and fresh marshmallows, although I felt the marshmallows were too sweet for my tastes. Didn't 't matter though because I wiped out the chocolate bread entirely. 

I knocked off a star because the little candle didn't keep the cheese/chocolate as warm as I wished. Otherwise, it's a great (and cheaper) alternative to the Melting Pot.
author: Nancie T.

description:
Just fantastic!  Fondues were excellent.
On a side note, my wife did not like her wine selection and they immediately gave her three win tastings (without asking) to assist in making a favorable selection.
Definitely make reservations for table seating.  We dined at the bar and it was terrific. 
Good food, friendly accommodating staff, pleasant atmosphere, and reasonable pricing.  What more could you ask for?
author: R H.

description: Called in 15 mins ahead and got a table for 2 once we arrived! Ordered the happy trails (dark chocolate with a touch of cayenne), it came with fresh fruits and other goodies. It was soooo delicious! Even though it was a busy evening, the service was great and attentive . Will come back next time to try the cheese fondue. What an excellent way to end the date night!
author: Melody F.

description: The food and service was amazing! Will definitely go back the next time we are in the city.
author: n d.

description:
This place is a great alternative to the overpriced fondue places. 

Came here with a girlfriend and we shared the Manchego fondue and the dark chocolate with cayenne dessert. Both were very delicious and reasonably priced!

Would love to come back with a big group and sample some more cheeses!
author: Lauren F.

description:
The fondue pots are tiny.  Very tiny.   But you get lots of things to dip into the petite pots, including some truly addictive roasted potatoes and - the surprise of the night - baby gherkins.  Baby gherkins and cheese has to be the biggest pickle revelation I've had since someone introduced me to fried pickles at a hole-in-the-wall joint in Memphis.

Not that this is a hole-in-the-wall - no, no, no.  Fondue Cowboy is made up of clean, modern lines and a plentiful wine list to complement several varieties of gooey gourmet cheese pots.  And they have wine on tap; a trend that I'm happy to see is growing.  

However, in a world where size does sometimes matter, I was bothered by the ratio of fondue vs what I paid for it.  It was a bit pricy for that very tiny pot.   I'll put this on the list of potential cute date night options, but it's not at the top of the list.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
My Aunt visited from out of town so I wanted to find something in the city that was different and exciting.

This restaurant is definitely not in the heart of the city and might take a bit longer to get too during rush hour so plan according. 

We had a reservation for 5:30 but were 30 minutes late because of street traffic. Their staff was very understanding and it ended up that they weren't crowded at all.

We ordered the Outlaw cheese fondue which was very good! The sides they provide for dipping are very creative and some things like the pickles and olives I would have never thought of using.

The dessert fondue was wonderful. We ordered the milk chocolate and tried to finish as much as we could. The portions are enough for 2-3 people so it would probably be best to share.

I would recommend this restaurant if you are looking for more of an intimate setting. It is very small but definitely not as noisy and cramped as most places in the city.
author: Jena S.

description:
I LOVE fondue and went here with great expectations.  My grandma and I were sorely disappointed to see that they only had cheese or chocolate for fondue.  

We ordered the Mixed Greens, Roasted Pear and Gorgonzola Salad and found it bland - the bacon at the bottom of the bowl tasted like rubber, there was not a lot of dressing, and the salad didn't taste fully washed (you know that gritty taste).  

We ordered the fondue with French compte (I think), garlic, and mushrooms (I can't remember the name and it's not listed on their on-line menu).  When the cheese fondue arrived I was surprised - the heat source was not a traditional fondue pot, but a tea light which is generally not strong enough to keep cheese heated enough to keep from coagulating, as was the case last night.  The pot was SO small for the cheese, we could have each had one and been fine.  Also, the portions of dipping items compared to cheese was so skewed - usually you have more cheese than dipping items.  The dipping items were fine (cheese, potatoes, pickles, olives, grapes, broccoli, apple) but cut into too small of pieces to really hold cheese.    

When all the cheese had been scraped from the bottom of the small pot and the extra items munched on we were still hungry so we ordered the white chocolate fondue.  Again, a small pot (which for dessert was fine), and a lot of side items.  My grandma enjoyed the chocolate bread, madelines, and strawberries, while I enjoyed the strawberries, kiwi, bananas, and marshmallows.  Again, the fruit was cut too small to hold the chocolate easily.

I wanted to like it here: the atmosphere was great (my 94 year old Grandma kept saying how it would be such a fun spot for a party), the wine we ordered (cab and syrah) was yummy, however the cheese wasn't heated correctly and was WAY too small for a dinner, and the side items should be cut into a little larger chunks.  I think this would be a good place for happy hour or maybe before a show if you don't want a lot to eat.
author: Jill Fay R.

description:
"Save money on the bull, ride a cowboy." I have a boyfriend so that's out of the question but that's not stopping me from experiencing the Fondue Cowboy, a cheesy, gooey and in my opinion, much tastier version of the actual Western dude who wears spurs and Wranglers. 

Holy cow, what an amazing meal. We started out with The Outlaw which includes aged cheddar, jalapenos and beer. In it's company were all sorts of dipping morsels: sourdough bread, grapes, apples, pickles, potatoes and sausage (we ordered that for extra). When they plopped it down we didn't think it was going to be enough food but before we knew it, we were busting at the seems and hadn't even gotten half way through! 

I don't know how but we ordered the milk chocolate fondue pot for dessert. It came with a beautiful fruit platter (strawberries, kiwis, tangerines and bananas), chocolate sourdough bread, and marshmallows. We gave it a valiant effort but couldn't quite finish it. 

Their corkage fee is only $15 so we brought a bottle of our own wine. It was seriously, the perfect way to celebrate Valentines Day. You all should have V-Day envy. Unless, of course, you were like us and went to Fondue Cowboy in which case...did you enjoy the ride as much as we did?!
author: Julia N.

description: A great place for a party or a romantic date.  I also took my 11 year old nephew there and he loved it too!  The bartenders and waitstaff are really friendly.  I've gone when we had a reservation and walked in too with no problem.  Although, I'd definitely recommend making a reservation, especially if you have a party larger than two people.
author: R. B.

description: Pretty good. The best part was the mixed green salad. Portions were small. I felt like there was no main dish and I wanted dinner afterward, even though I was unpleasantly full. Weird feeling. Hip space. Nice skinny SF waiter. Wouldn't rush back, but fun for the novelty.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Sometimes you come across a pairing that makes you go, "hmmm." 

Fondue + Cowboys is one of those "hmmm" themes for me, but happily the result of this unlikely match is a tasty one.

We went with 3 of the fondues: The Outlaw, The Rawhide and another one that I can't for the life of me remember, which is okay because the winner was definitely The Outlaw. The aged cheddar, the beer and a little kick with the jalapenos hit it out of the park. Very deelish.

We also ordered the cured meat plate and the Louisiana hot links. Both were stellar. As for wine, the Granache is a delight.

All in all, I was happy with my meal and it's kind of hard not to enjoy a place with an illustration of Clint Eastwood on the wall. Again, it makes no sense to me, but sometimes things that make no sense are the best things in life. 

Go with it and enjoy!
author: Stephy S.

description: Was amazing. Both the owner and all the staff were so inviting along with serving some wonderful food.
author: Dustin Y.

description: We loved our meal here! The portions do appear to be on the small side, but the meal is quite filling. I thought that the portion was reasonable for the price. We didn't have a chance to try the dessert fondue but we will definitely try it on our next visit. The service was polite and efficient. I recommend checking this place out, but you'll want to make a reservation for sure!
author: Diana G.

description:
I really wanted to love Fondue Cowboy. I was disappointed that I didn't.

I had never had cheese fondue before, only chocolate, so I was expecting cheese similar to that on a hot pizza. Stringy, gooey, delicious. It wasn't what I expected. We ordered the Outlaw which had way too strong of a beer taste to it. I couldn't taste the cheese at all! The beer flavor completely overpowered everything I was eating. My group also ordered the sausages to come with the Outlaw -- that was a normal plate of sausages.

I could have lived without the side of olives and pickles that came with the fondue as well.

For dessert, we had the dark chocolate and cayenne pepper. This is the type of fondue that I am used to! I could have done with less cayenne though, personally. It had a strong kick. 

Overall, I would give the food 2 stars but 4 stars for service. I used my Groupon deal for this meal.
author: Stefanie S.

description:
I love cheese and I love dipping things into cheese. Last week I was looking through my bookmark and came across Fondue Cowboy. Went through my phone book to scout for those that would join me for a cheesy dinner. (Not many of my friends like cheese)
Lucky for me, I found two. 

Based on the reviews on yelp, I was eager to get to the restaurant early because yelpers seem to claim that the place is always packed and the wait is averaged to be 45 - 60 minutes long.  We arrived around 630 and the place was empty. It didn't fill up later that evening either. It was a Thursday. (I thought Thursday is the new Friday?)

Within the three of us, we shared two cheese fondue and a chocolate fondue. For the cheese fondue, we ordered The Outlaw (Aged cheddar, beer, slow roasted tomatoes, roasted garlic, roasted jalapeno and cilantro) and The Stage Coach (Compte cheese, white wine, roasted and garlic)

The outlaw was okay but the stage coach... no bueno. Both of the cheeses were pretty bland but because I only had those two to compare, I'll have to say that the outlaw was the better choice. 

The chocolate fondue was our favorite! I walked in expecting their cheese to blow my mind but the chocolate fondue totally came up as the underdog. We got the Happy Trails (Dark Chocolate with cayenne) and it was so delicious! Not a fan of dark chocolate nor the idea of putting cayenne pepper into melted chocolate but the combo turned out to be the best dish of the night!

Would I go back for their cheese fondue? Probably not, but I would for a happy trail!

3 stars for the chocolate fondue.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Tonight was my first visit. We had the Traditional, the Stage Coach and the one with the Jalapeno. No meat platter; just the bread, potato, veg and olives. Dark chocolate fondue with cayenne for dessert. 

What a lovely evening. Good food, friendly, prompt service, mellow atmosphere and good company. I had the Sangria. I will be recommending this place to my colleagues who have been wanting to go.
So nice to go somewhere where everything was good. Yes, little cauldrons of cheese and chocolate will soothe a soul!
author: Shivaun O.

description: GREAT service. Wonderful people. We got the last one on the menu for cheeses then we got the buckaroo chocolate desert and it was all wonderful!!! I will return soon.
author: Luke L.

description:
This was my first time trying fondue, so that's a disclaimer for all my opinions on the cheese fondue. Don't kill me!

Ordered the Rawhide fondue because it had some yummy bacon and Louisiana hot links. It came with apples, broccoli, bread, grapes, small toasted pieces, bread

Pros:
-great service, the waiter was friendly and refilled drinks occasionally.
-cowboy themed place looks modern and fun. We got the window corner seat, so there were nice pillows. So comfortable!
- great value, it's hard to find fondue for only $24 per pot in SF.

Cons:
-I don't usually drink alcohol, so the fondue came off as really heavy on the alcohol. Again, if you are used to alcohol, then disregard.

*Also, make sure you order a meat plate of some sort. You won't be full with just a pot of fondue. 
*Make reservations, the place fills up quickly
author: Glo Y.

description:
There's nothing cowboy about fondue, and there is nothing fondue about cowboy.  So the fact that the two were combined to christen a restaurant was somewhat curious, if not unusual. 

But okay.  I don't care so much about the name if the food and service are up to par.

But before I start discussing the food, let me begin by saying that they have a pretty cool setup.  The cowboy theme was continued throughout via the big flat screen TV with The Good, The Bad and The Ugly on repeat, the interior heavily dominated with cherry wood laminate, and a couple of massive wall decals.  Yet said theme was carried with much taste so as to not be off-putting to those who are not a big fan of the wild, wild west (present company included).   So kudos to the interior designer. 

After perusing the menu the five of us settled for the amazing heirloom tomato salad and mixed greens, roasted pear and gorgonzola salad.   The Outlaw, The Stage Coach and The Quick Draw, all of which are cheese fondue and came with accompaniments - fresh-cut brocolli, olives, grapes, apples, roast potatoes and bread.  As us carnivores needed meat, we also ordered the a side of cured meat and sausages.   

While the other two cheese fondues were tasty, it was quickly determined that the Outlaw was everyone's favorite.  With cheddar, roasted tomatoes, garlic, and jalapeno, it almost tasted like an Atkins-friendly pizza if you dip a slice of salami (from the cured meat platter).  Anyone who isn't buying into the whole Atkins fad can definitely add the toasted crostini or bread and, voila, you have a complete pizza!
author: Ange L.

description:
Been wanting to visit for awhile and they did not disappoint. 
2 of us shared the desperado, because goat cheese is my favorite. It was awesome. Just the right hint of sherry flavor and the added mushrooms added to the earthiness of the dish. We followed it up with the milk chocolate dessert fondue which was dreamy. The best part is that they serve it with pieces of dark chocolate baguette from Pinkies, another of our favorites. 

Excellent, attentive service and fun to share on a date. 

We will be back for sure !
author: C V.

description:
I can see why reservations are highly recommended.  The place is...intimate.  The host/waiter was very accomodating.  We arrived without a reservation, but were there early enough to be seated without one.  

The names of the choices of fondues was a lot of fun and the variety was good.  The dipping items were ample and we had plenty left over.  We did order the sausage plate which was a tasty addition.

I enjoyed my meal and the prices were very reasonable.  I will certainly be back with a larger group so that we may try more fondue combos and have one of the chocolate choices.
author: Christine W.

description:
I'd been searching for a fondue spot that wasn't Melting Pot during the four years since moving to San Francisco and came up with nothing. Then, I searched again a few months ago, and lo and behold, found Fondue Cowboy had opened last summer. So I grabbed my husband and some friends and made a reservation for a Friday night.

The service was oh-so-friendly, the food was awesome, and they had amazing sangria for $8 per overflowing glass. We had two types of cheese and two types of chocolate for dessert, as well as the meat/salami platter to dip in the cheese (it only comes with breads and veggies, no meat), and the bill came out to about $30 a person for four people. Definitely less than we usually pay for a huge dinner out in San Francisco!

The space is intimate so I recommend making a reservation on weekend nights (which you can do on Open Table). And street parking in that area (a little ways out in SoMa on Folsom) is super easy. I'm already looking forward to going back!
author: Kristin L.

description: I lived in Switzerland for a year. I was perhaps too young to appreciate fondue. (I was a bit too young perhaps to appreciate wine, I guess! I used to love "raclette"! :-) ) All I can say is that Fondue Cowboy has brought back a lot of memories. The great thing about fondue is in the sharing of a pot, in the communal experience, in the "dip," the "dippers," the dippings, and the deep-ends! (if you have too much, I guess! haha!) :-) Fondue Cowboy excels on all these. Again, I was a guest. My friends ordered for two. Three ate. One more cool thing! :-)
author: Nando G.

description:
My bff and I went here last night. We were both floored that this place was not new! We are in this specific block radius of SOMA more than anywhere else in the city for the past 3.5 years and have not only never seen this place nor heard it's cute name! And I have searched restaurants in this 4 block radius so many times on Yelp that it is just shocking this place has been here for 4 years. 
It is in a highly unassuming local and kinda covered by a big tree so you would have no clue it was here driving past it. 
The ambiance was a little rustic, yet eclectic. I expected more of a modern saloon, but it wasn't really like that. The only western aspect seemed to be the vintage western films projected on the wall at the bar. 
The cocktail menu was awesome! Super creative and yummy drinks. I got the strawberry mojito and it was fabulous! The only way someone could not love it is if they are a freak who hates strawberries! They also had a wine and I think beer menu. 
The fondue options are super limited, but shockingly, super creative and awesome! We got the Traditional and then the Happy Trails for the chocolate one. Both were insanely good and the perfect amounts. We were so stuffed leaving. Our waitress was so sweet and friendly. She was really genuine and kind. We left and forgot this piece of paper on the table and she actually ran out after us to our car. So CUTE! Definitely would return many times over.
author: Unicorn U.

description:
Let me start by getting out the way the 2 reasons why not 5 stars.

First, the fondue portion: way too small. 
You see, I come from Europe where the amount of fondue they give you for 2 people would be about 5 times more than what you get at Fondue Cowboy. 
Yes I know, different country, different style; you don't get free soda refills in any restaurant in Europe. But still, I was a bit disappointed.
Second, the price... a bit expensive for what you get.

That being said I really did enjoy the place!
Unlike with the fondue, the amount of dipping stuff was very good, as was the amount of meat you get on the cured meat platter.
I did enjoy the variety of accompaniments they give you with the fondue (apples, pickles, broccolis, grapes).
We had the traditional fondue, which was very good and pretty close to the Swiss stuff; it could use a bit more salt and white wine though.
Service was great too; our server gave us very good recommendations. 

The wine list is a bit small, but includes some very good wines.
And the decor is really, really cool. So is the ambiance. I loved it.

I will definitely go back but I wish they would make the fondue portion a bit bigger!
author: Vithiet L.

description:
Yee haw! This place is great! It's small, so I HIGHLY recommend making reservations, even if you're a small party.

I came here for my birthday with some friends and we had a chocolate-y cheezy good time! I'd say that one of the pots of their fondue is good to share with 3-4 people. Our party got the Happy Trails (dark chocolate with cayenne) and Buck-a-Roo (milk chocolate with walnuts) for sweet fondues. For the savory fondues, got the Traditional (Swiss, White Wine, garlic, nutmeg) and the Outlaw (Aged Cheddar, beer, tomatoes, garlic, jalapeno)! I absolutely LOVED the sweet fondues! There was a nice warming in the back of my throat after Happy Trails :)
The restaurant provides all the accompaniments to the fondues, which was awesome! The sweet fondues came with fruits, madeline cookies, mini marshmallows, and some sort of chocolate chip bread(?)
The savory fondues came with bread, potatoes, green apples, grapes, broccoli, olives, and mini pickles! Be warned: the olives were quite salty and the pickles were preeeeetty sour! Just drench them in cheese though and it won't be as bad.

At first glance, items on the menu might seem expensive, but everything is actually very reasonably priced! Fondue is to be shared, so when everything is split at the end, it's not bad at all! My party got 4 different fondues, plus the cured meat plate and in the end, people paid ~$11 each!

The service was excellent and everyone who was working was really nice! They constantly kept our water glasses filled and they made sure we were happy with everything. Over by the bar, there's a screen that shows old black and white Westerns too! :)

I want to try all the other savory and sweet fondues, so I'll be back for sure!

Also, parking can be kind of difficult in the area.
author: Kei H.

description:
I didn't know what the heck a fondue cowboy was before dining in, and after having dinner here I still don't know--but it's been two weeks and I'm still drooling over this place!!  Five Stars!!!!!!!!!

The menu is small, but the food is great!  And the outstanding service was a major plus.  The decor was fun yet elegant--I love the black and white cowboy films playing on the flat screen at the bar.  The low lighting and background western-themed music makes this place date-appropriate, or great for catching up with a friend.  You'll need to make reservations if you don't want to snag seats at the bar.  There are only 6-7 tables. 

Any fondue you order comes with unlimited dipping items, so don't think you can't get full off of fondue--you definitely can!

For wine, we ordered the syrah which was on tap.  My overall opinion of it was meh, but it lacked a bitter after taste which was awesome.  The beet salad was delicious: arugula, walnuts, beets, and goat cheese, yum.  I will definitely re-create it at home.  For our entree, we ordered "The Outlaw" which came highly recommended--and it did not disappoint.  I liked it best with broccoli for dipping, but we had an ample selection of veggies and carby-things to choose from.   

For dessert, you must try the "Happy Trails."  Dark chocolate and cayenne pepper fondue may sound kind of funky, but it is heaven on earth!  The quality of the chocolate here is very good--and I normally wouldn't say such a thing, because I'mma chocolate snob.  The name of the brand escapes me, but the chocolate comes from the same supplier as see's candies, and it is a local chocolate company that moved to the bay from France in the late 1800s.  Almost as exciting as the fondue was the dippers it came with: fresh fruit, mandelines, and home made marsh mallows--oh my!    

The location for cowboy fondue felt kind of random--but it was only about a 10 minute walk from The Orpheum.  I'm not in this area very often, but I will most definitely venture back here for some fabulous dessert!
author: Jatinder S.

description:
I'll keep it short...I like this place.  Fondue with friends is always a good time and Fondue Cowboy provides a fun, comfortable atmosphere so you can fully enjoy the food and your company.   Full bar, good food and reasonable prices. What else is there?  You won't be seeing me at that other place on Van Ness for awhile.

Edit: Went here again last night....This place is still off the chain but they do get busy so make a reservation if ya can especially for parties larger than two(they are on OpenTable).  
&
Sharing the Rawhide(so good) and cured meat plate(also so good) was the perfect amount of grub for my date and I.
author: Eric V.

description:
One of a kind, intimate, fun and yum yum yum!!
Being a neat freak, I love the idea of my food cut in bite size, dipped in fondue and every bit is a piece of heaven. Since there's no "cooking" in their kitchen, I love the clean feel of this place.

The portion is just right for two people so make sure you go with someone who would like the same fondue. It comes with these finger size potatoes, sourdough, green apples, grapes, olives and pickles and yes, you can tell them if you don't like certain things on your plate. 

We have the Outlaw minus the jalapeno which the chedder flavor really came through, the texture, consistency and flavor was perfect, not too cheesy and not to salty. 

Service was excellent and pair it with your favorite will make this one of your most memorable meal!!

I love it and can't wait to come back!!
author: Maggie C.

description:
Found myself here when I had an urge to dip something!!!!

Pros: 
1. Great variety of cheese, that they melt themselves in the back
2. Each platter comes with a good variety of dippers

Cons:
1. Small restaurant, limited seating
2. The waiters are super slow and non-responsive (terrible service)

I would come here again only because I like fondue and the sweet fondue was amazing.

Advice:
- Make sure you order a meat plate otherwise the food isn't very filling.
author: Chirag V.

description:
Was so excited when a Living Social deal popped up for Fondue Cowboy. I've experienced several great fondue spots in my time, though I had yet to visit any since moving to SF.

The space is great! It's small, well designed, with cool decor. It is an awesome date night spot.

The staff was really friendly, and the drinks (though not a full bar) were tasty. I recommend giving the sangria a whirl!

We started with a really refreshing white bean salad which was fantastic. 

We ordered the traditional fondue with a side sausage platter for dinner. While I thought the fondue was tasty, I was a bit disappointed in the dipping options. It was a random assortment... some were great (fresh bread, apples, olives)... some were strange (pickles, hard crouton baguette slices). In the end the fondue experience just wasn't as good as I've had at other places. 

Great ambiance, good drinks, a mixed-bag of delicious bites. I might return, but will probably check out other fondue places first.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Came here with a group of nine last night for my birthday and really liked it.  Although the food menu is fairly small, the fondue itself was really good - and that's what this place is all about anyway.  It is a teeny tiny place, so you should probably make a reservation.  

As far as the ordering process, I would say one order of fondue can probably serve two people (unless you're absolutely starving, in which case you could get sides, etc.).  With the savory fondues (all cheese), you get bread, potatoes, broccoli, olives and little cornichons.  With the sweet fondues you get chocolate bread, normal bread, madeleines and marshmallows.  You can order a meat or sausage plate as a side, and they also have a few salads.

It was a cool place to check out with a group because we had the opportunity to try a lot of different things.  I would definitely come again to try what we didn't get to the first time around.
author: KT R.

description:
What a find. Cool little spot that does tasty fondue and won't break the bank. This place makes me regret spending any money at this other unnamed chain fondue place in San Mateo. 20 dollars for a cheese fondue enough to be shared by two people. Add a salad and you have a full meal. We ordered two salads and one fondue and didn't have room for desert which we wish we did.

So we ordered the traditional fondue which was tasty. Came with bread, fingerling potatoes some fruit and veges. They also have wine on tap which was surprisingly good. Nice selection of beers and wine. Also had a hard cider that was awesome. 

The decor was really cool and the staff was nice nice but not overbearing which was nice so you can get lost in conversation and yet get anything you needed.
author: Hyung L.

description:
Like some of the other Yelp reviewers,  I came here for a Grubwithus meal. The service first of all was great. The food kept coming and the waiter was super nice. Everything was served family style, but they were great about providing us with plenty of food. 

We started with a roasted beet salad which was delicious (the waiter actually gave us a choice of salad which he totally didn't have to do). Then a meat and melon platter. I don't eat meat, but others at the table really seemed to enjoy the two together. Then we were served the cheese fondue with veggies, pickles, bread, and potatoes. There were three types of fondue - a traditional gruyere, a manchego, and a cheddar with jalepenos. All the were pretty good, but the manchego was by far the best. 

For the dessert course, they served fruit, bread, and marshmallows with two types of chocolate fondue. A milk chocolate with hazelnut and a white chocolate with strawberry. I liked the milk chocolate one better. My only complaint was that I was hoping the pumpernickle bread was actually brownie bites for the dessert course!
author: Vrushali P.

description:
I have had fondue (or raglette) every night for a week in a cabin in the French Alps, and I can tell you, less the snow, fireplace, and smell of wet ski pants, this place is up there for fondue.  

Staff is kind, helpful and knows their menu well.   I always find it very important that a waiter knows the food they serve intimately.  Nothing worse than a server that doesn't know $hit about what they are serving.  

Anyway,  there are some variations of cheese that the Swiss and French would probably BALK at, but hey... this is San Francisco and it is fine to do your own thing.  I had the earthy tasting cheese with the mushrooms and garlic cooked into (I forget the name).  The meat plate is great.  No complaints whatsoever about this place.  

The price is the biggest winner....  I mean a fondue plate for 20 bucks for two people....  We couldn't even finish ours.....  

If you are in SF, try out this place.  Won't disappoint.
author: Ross B.

description:
Décor:  Beautiful.
Reservation:  Successful.
Waiter service:  Lots of annoying delays.
Menu:  There is NO oil fondue!  There are:
  * 5 types of cheese fondues
  * 3 or 4 salads
  * 2 meat plates
  * 3 dessert fondues (dark, milk, and white chocolates)

Portion size:  Kind of inadequate. Too little fondue for the amount of dipping items provided.
Fondue itself:  Most were tasty, but the "Traditional" was bitter, sour, and way too lacking in salt. 
Dipping items:  
  * Apples (not enough)
  * Bread (obvi)
  * Potatoes (okay, sure)
  * Grapes (cool)
  * Honeydew & canteloupe (weird, but whatever)
  * RAW broccoli (couldn't they blanche it??)
  * Pickles (for dipping in cheese?? gross!)
  * Olives (also gross when dipped in cheese!)

Overall:  

This place was a let-down compared to every other fondue restaurant I've been to (a total of 5 or 6 across the US), and was especially a let-down given the price and the hype.  

The dessert was the most redeeming quality. While this place wasn't that satisfying as a meal, it would probably be a great place for just dessert.
author: Ashley M.

description:
Fondue Cowboy - The place is so cool, nobody can get in

I wish yelp had an option for zero stars! Fondue Cowboy, even though I have thought of nothing but enjoying your fondue goodness since I read about you & have been so excited for something fun & new in the SF restaurant scene, you will never get my business.

I called a week and a half ago to make a reservation for this Wednesday night. The gentleman I spoke with, whom I believe is the owner, was very friendly. He explained to me that they do not take reservations...not even for parties of 6 or more. Also, he said several times that my friends and I would have no problem getting a table on a Wednesday. Thanks for the reassurance dude! It's was worthless!!

One person from our group showed up 30 minutes earlier than the rest  just in case there was a short wait. The staff was not welcoming, rude and said there would be a 1.5 hour wait!!!!!! Then rudely gave her the "didn't you make a reservation". Well um, we would had you let us!

If you are now taking reservations, post it on your website. I've looked at the website multiple times and it ain't on there! Also, when guests arrive that would like to give you their money, don't act like dicks. This is San Francisco and restaurants are a dime a dozen. Your attitude and quickness to make people wait ridiculous amounts of time will get you absolutely nowhere. 

So, we took our business elsewhere to a more welcoming spot, spent $300, left a great tip and had a fab time. Sucks for you cowboy!
author: Kandace K.

description:
Cute fondue place. I love the Western theme and the fondue is way better than the run of the mill stuff at Melting Pot. 

2 fondues (1 cheese, 1 dessert) are more than enough for 2 people. They provide more than enough dippers and cheese both (unless you're particularly hungry). We got the Happy Trails and the Outlaw and they were both delicious. I also love that the dippers here are unusual (pickles with cheese, chocolate bread with chocolate). 

All in all, super cute place for a date or a girl's night out.
author: Shreya O.

description: Really friendly - came in before closing time and the chocolate fondue was just what I needed with fruits to dip. The chocolate bread was a bit strange - kind of salty? But everything else was delicious and they gave us more banana when we ran out! Now that's service.
author: Ara S.

description:
YAY melted cheese!  YAYAYAYAYAY!  

Husband and I came here to celebrate our seventh anniversary to continue the tradition of fondueversaries.  Unlike Fondue Fred where we usually get ridiculous cheese and cheap wine hangovers, the Cowboy is hipster classy.  Granted, a little much with the thumping house music and low lighting, but I dug it.  The service was excellent - attentive and kind - plus, our server treated us to two free drinks for our special day!  We wished for more fondue (cheese and chocolate).  The pots are a bit small - but the dippers are plentiful and delicious.  Meat platter was great.  

It is expensive for the amount, but I was glad to pay it for the service and quality.  We'll be back... and hopefully, the cheese pot will get larger!  :)
author: Natalie M.

description:
I was looking for someplace different to take the future wife and came across this place through a friend. 

It's located not too far away from the Powell Street Bart station. We took a cab since it was raining.  

The fondue was really good and I'm giving it 4-stars but the tables are too close together (reason I'm not giving it a 5-star). The seating arrangement made it feel as if we were eating with the people next to us. 

Other than the seating, we will be back! 

Really cool decor and great theme for a fondue place.
author: Shaun D.

description:
I have to agree with Jorge E. -  if you want large quantities of food for super cheap or free, go back to your mom's kitchen.  If you want to get what you pay for and have a nice experience, come to Fondue Cowboy.

A couple of my friends and I went to Fondue Cowboy on it's third day open, and our experience was a pleasure.  The service was friendly, the food was tasty, and the prices were appropriate for what we got.  

We ordered one savory fondue per head, and had fun sharing and sampling the recommendations of our server (just ask them what they eat ... ).  Unlike some of the other reviewers, we had plenty of cheese to accommodate our dippers ... in fact, we asked for extra dippers (no extra charge) because we still had some cheese left.  I think if you actually dip your veggies or bread rather than using them as spoons, you'll be plenty satisfied with the portions.

For dessert, we chose the dark chocolate and white chocolate fondues.  They brought us strawberries, grapes as well as these delicious cookie-type things from the bakery around the corner.  YUM!  My suggestion to you if you think your white chocolate is a tad too thin is to let it simmer a little more ... it caramelizes nicely, and the flavor is a tad nutty.

About the beverages, we were curious about the wines they have on tap and were allowed to do some sampling before settling on a nice red wine blend.  Surprisingly, the tap wine was delicious and complemented our fondue well.  Another bonus is that the price was really reasonable by the carafe.

If you come here intending to enjoy your experience and have an open mind, you will love it.  If you are the type who comes to an establishment dying to find the negatives so you can run home to your computer to Yelp about how it was sooo beneath you, you should stay home -- free up the tables for the people with good juju who will actually enjoy themselves.
author: Jenny K.

description:
The fondue is great, although if you're expecting this place to be just like the melting pot but cheaper then you're going to be disappointed. 

On the phone they told us that one order of fondue was enough to serve 2-3 people, so at $15 per order that seemed like a steal. So when we got there we tried ordering two sets of fondue for four people, but this was nowhere near enough for dinner. If you want to make a meal of this then you would really need one order per person, plus maybe a plate of the cured meats for every two people. They are clearly marketing themselves as a restaurant, although in reality it's more of a bar that's set up to serve  small portions of fondue with your drinks. Which would have been fine, but it's just not what we were expecting.

After dinner we ordered two sets of chocolate fondue for the table, and that seemed like enough chocolate to satisfy the four of us. The dark was good, although the white chocolate was my favorite. Strange since I'd never actually order a white chocolate bar, but with the fruit and bread that they gave us it worked quite well.

All in all the food was very tasty. However, to get enough food to make a dinner of it then realistically it would be about $30 per person. So in the end it's only ten bucks cheaper than melting pot, for significantly less food. I wouldn't normally complain about portions and pricing at a restaurant, but even the 5'0 100lb girl I was with said she was going to go home and make gnocchi after. So if you're looking for drinks and a little fondue, this place is a winner. But for dinner I think there are probably better options, especially since the place was fairly noisy and doesn't take reservations.
author: Alex K.

description:
Yelp Review Haiku:
Delicious cheesy goodness.  
I ate way too much.

Order the Quickdraw.  
Manchego Roasted Peppers
Perfection in cheese.

I'd eat here daily
If cheese had no calories
and it were cheaper.
author: Meghan S.

description:
Opening night.  8 people.  9:30 pm.  4 cheese fondues.  2 beers.  2 bottles of old vine zin.  Kitchen stays open for us (WHAT?) to make three chocolate fondues.

Adorable server, fantastic food (who doesn't like bacon in cheese?), delicious and incredibly reasonably priced wine, and a fun ambiance.  Check total: $160 before tip (again, WHAT??).

This place is freakin' awesome.  Go.
author: Caitlin M.

description:
You could not pay me to eat here again. While I love the idea of cuddling up to my date with some delicious fondue, this was far from the experience I had last night. We ordered the Outlaw fondue (this should be outlawed for the lack of taste and price that they were charging for it, not worth it!)

It consists of: Aged Cheddar, Beer, Slow Roasted Tomatoes, Roasted Garlic, Roasted Jalapeno, Cilantro (sounds pretty yummy, right?) Well, they served it with dry, overcooked potatoes (ick) and a few pieces of bread that were fitting for feeding the birds and then the biggest disappointment is what they paired the fondue with -- this was the most unappealing platter of red grapes next to broccoli next to Greek olives next to little pickles next to green apples. It looked and tasted as if we got the left overs on everyone's order. Not only did it "not" go well with the actual fondue but it was lacking any sort of creativity or presentation. I know this is no Gary Danko's but how hard it is to pair it with food that actually enhances the cheese flavor and looks appealing?

It's over-priced for food you can make at home but trust me, you probably would not. Nothing was satisfying except for the salad but again, small salad priced at $8 - is it worth it? I think not!

Dig up your fondue set at home and save yourself a trip from this place.
author: Stacia F.

description:
I'm the kind of person that orders extra nachos cheese and sides of nacho cheese for things that don't come with nacho cheese!  I love cheese sauce, and I don't have high standards for it.  So Fondue Cowboy started off in a position of authority, but didn't follow through.  

FC could be an A-OK experience with time, but right now I wouldn't recommend it to others.  If you want to eat in that area, better to go to Bossa Nova right now.  

The decor is okay; my only major beef with it is the shade of beige used on the bar wall.  They could have gone with something bolder. But no stars off for that.    

The menu feels incomplete.  It's too expensive to satisfy your need to snack, and yet you'll have a hard time making dinner out of it considering the price and the calories involved.  Adding some steaks and chicken to the menu would go a long way to making the restaurant more suitable for dinner.  

And it would also go a long way in cowboying the place up!  Really, fondue cowboy?! Besides the old shoot 'em up films playing silently and (as Ed U says) the giddy-up names of the fondue pots not much smacks of the old west.  

Onto the actual food.  We had the Outlaw and another savory fondue not on their online menu that had mushrooms in it.  Both were good, but I would have liked the cheddar-based Outlaw to have been sharper and spicier.  We had a discussion about whether sharp cheese melts well though...so maybe it doesn't make good fondue. I don't know.  In general the cheese was not my issue.  I love cheese.   

The starch fixings are okay, but there's a problem with the others.  Kalamata olives?! Not cowboy and not good (and these weren't good ones).  The broccoli?! I would have appreciated if it had been at least blanched.  

The salumi plate was a rip-off.  At $16 I was opposed to ordering it but my companion insisted.  The prosciutto, coppa and sopressata were not that very good and sliced way to think. It also came with a lot of out of season melon, which did nothing for me.  Why even do Italian cold cuts somewhere "cowboy"?! 

I did have a green salad with Gorgonzola and pears that was very good.  I asked for pepper and it came in a little silver bowl.  The salad was good, but there has to be a better way to give someone pepper...

...there is actually. It's called a pepper mill.  And Fondue Cowboy should definitely get one.  

To review: they need to spice the place (and their fondue) up a bit.  They need to add some entrees (you expect any place with cowboy in the name to serve a flank steak).  And they need to polish up their offerings by getting some basic amenities like pepper mills and ditch the crappy Kalamata olives, mountains of pickles and giant hunks of raw broccoli.
author: Luke M.

description:
With a name like 'Fondue Cowboy', you can't help but expect great things.  If you're looking for a hefty, meat-centric meal, this isn't the place to go.  It's definitely more of a bar with food than a restaurant.

We ordered the meat plate to start off with, then 2 savory fondues: the Outlaw (aged cheddar, slow roasted tomatoes, garlic, jalapeno) and the Rawhide (gorgonzola, emmenthale, white wine and bacon) and the Outlaw was by far the better of the two. (keep in mind this was for four people).

For Dessert, we had the dark chocolate with cayenne, and it was really delicious. The cayenne adds the perfect bit of spice to the meal.

I left this place feeling pretty hungry.  On the one hand, you can continue to order more fondue to make yourself full, but I reached my fondue limit pretty quickly and wanted something more substantial in my tummy.

Great food, great service, just not very filling as  a "dinner place".
author: Jenny S.

description: Me and my girlfriend have been here a few times. We have always had a great experience. On our last visit we had the Outlaw, the Cured Meat Plate and for desert we always go for the Buck-a-roo. Their food is delicious and at first seems like a small portion but once you get going it really fills you up. The ambience is great and the staff is always ready to assist you. It's a great place to come for a romantic date or a large group of friends. Fondue Cowboy definitely blows any other fondue place I have been to out of the water.
author: Fernando P.

description:
you know i am getting sick of people who complain about price as the only negative. this place is not that expensive by any means. I don't think all these so called foodies really know how much it cost to do business in our beautiful city. with mandatory sick pay, health care and a higher minimum wage than any other city. not to mention a San Francisco payroll tax that will choke a friggen horse what do you expect. you want cheap dining go to Modesto or Tracy. 

now on to the food. this place is killer. the service was outstanding and friendly and all around great time well worth the price. i wont get into any one specific plate as we were a pretty large table and we had a wide variety that we all shared and it was all good. don't hesitate to try this place it rocks
author: Jorge E.

description:
This is a good fondue place. Quality cheese. I've been to other fondue places but this one by far tops them all. This is a great place to go with friends or on a date since you are sharing a fondue and forced to converse with the person across from you.

It's small though so I definitely recommend doing a reservation just in case.
author: Michelle L.

description:
My friend chose this restaurant for her birthday. I am not sure what happened with our reservation but we had to wait for 45 minutes. The wait was fine because it was understandable because the place is so small and luckily there is a bar area where we could all stand around and catch up. 
The decor is nice and the staff friendly. This was my first fondue experience and I was pretty happy with the food. We tried four different types of fondue, the classic flavor being the group favorite. 
The highlight of the night was the Dark Chocolate with Cayenne desert, it was incredible! I want to go there later just for dessert. 
Great little place.
author: Jenny M.

description:
Four stars for their service and playing one of my favorite sci-fi action movie: Ultraviolet!

It's a cool place, modern and sleek.  There are seatings at the bar to your left or the bench seating to the right.  The best table is the corner one, which we ended up seating and allowed us to watch the movie together.

Very limited menu so shouldn't take long to decide - there are 5 savory fondue ($17 each), 3 sweet fondue ($14 each), 3 types of salad ($7 each) and side dish of cured sliced meats ($16).

The savory fondue comes with a plate of bread cubes, a few slices of grilled toast and potatoes and another dish of cubed apples, broccoli florets, cornihons and grapes. 

We had:
The cured sliced meats plate - it was good

The Outlaw - Aged cheddar, Beer, Slow Roasted tomatoes, Roasted Garlic, Roasted Jalapeno, Cilantro

The Stage Coach - Comte cheese, White wine, Roasted Garlic

They have a list of speciality cocktails, a list of wine available by the glass, 1/4 carafe, 1/2 carafe and bottle and beer by draft or bottle - all very reasonably priced.  

We had a 1/2 carafe of a blend - $15 - it was a bit sweet.

Our waiter, Kyle? was super friendly.  The other person behind the bar who also enjoys Ultraviolet as much as I do is also very friendly.  

We over ordered - one savory fondue would have been more than enough and perhaps allow us to try their sweet fondue.  Until next time - we can see this as a cozy go to place during winter time.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Cool new bar/lounge with cheese and chocolate fondues, salads and cured meats. Has a sleek-rustic atmosphere. Intimate space, lively crowd, super cute and attentive staff. 

Huge HD/bluray TV behind the bar playing a Clint Eastwood movie. So bizarrely realistic, feels like you are right there witnessing Shirley McLaine pull the arrow out from Clint's back. 

My husband and I sat at the bar, Lauren was the perfect bartender. She was helpful in guiding our selections, and also very sweet. 

It was all very moan-worthy! We had the roasted pear salad, the  fondue with comte cheese /mushroom and the dark chocolate fondue with cayenne. Serious yum! The flavor combinations hit just the right notes in the fondues and the salad was so fresh and interesting.   

We both had a glass of the cabernet blend, which was delicious. It was one of the wine selections on tap. Eco friendly and at a mere $6 a glass, wallet friendly too. I didn't think it was possible to pay so little for a good glass wine in SF. (You can also order a carafe for around $10!!). 

Will certainly be back soon to sample the cured meats, other fondues and salads.
author: Susan D.

description:
Sunday night, party of 6 (we made a reservation but probably wouldn't have needed it), good light meal made even better thanks to our excellent server.  

I haven't yelped in a while but wanted to add on a 4-star review because it was such a pleasant evening.

The Stage Coach was my favorite and Happy Trails could have had more cayenne for my taste, but was not bad by any means.  Would order every thing again.  Sangria & roasted beet salad were also a plus!  Will definitely be back.
author: TC C.

description:
Fodue Cowboy was a nice find!

Thanks to LivingSocial, I came upon this cool little place!  Easy on and off the freeway location, nice wine list and cool staff helped complete my positive expeprience here.

Thoroughly enjoyed the Quick Draw fondue but found The Outlaw to be the less tasty of the two...but don't get me wrong, they were both great.

I definitely recommend ordering a meat plate if you are more than just a tad hungry.  Even though FC is so generous with their wonderful, VERY fresh bread, olives, pickles, apples and veggies to dip, the meat plate really help round out the meal.  Unfortunately I didn't get a salad or try the chocolate fondues...we were so full, I couldn't justify paying $20 for a dessert I wouldn't come close to finishing.  Maybe a smaller version of dessert is called for to help those of us on the fence decide to say "Yes!" to the sweet enticements?  I also thought a sampler dessert fondue would be a nice touch.  

NOTE:  Two cheese fondues and two meat plates were WAY too much food for myself and my guy.  Don't be fooled by what others have written about the servings of cheese being too small...not true at all!

Will definitely be back to try more!
author: Christine B.

description:
Superb wait staff:  friendly, expedient, well spoken and informative!  (All of them:  we sat at the bar, side saddle.)

Ecclectic fondue:  personalize your order as  you wish.

Best Italian blueberry soda ever :)  Order it without ice, then have another while you settle in for dessert (this is one of those meals you can devour too quickly; take a good conversationalist to share the time to digest).
author: She F.

description: Im thinking 3.75 stars but rounding up due to holiday spirit? Small concise menu. A few fondue cheese combos where I went with the Manchego. Got the charcuterie and sausage platters to compliment the bread, potatoes, fruit and veggies. As a big eater, it was necessary to supplement those to be hunger satisfied. After that we shared a dark chocolate dessert version with cool chocolate bread/marshmallows/more fruit I like the concept but there is only so much you can do so I'm not sure about repeat dining. It does have a cool bar area and some decently creative drinks. Entertaining is the cowboy movie theme on the big screen and for some reason Madonna in various phases as the audio throughout the night.
author: Kim N.

description:
We had been looking forward to this restaurant opening for MONTHS!! The space is great, service good and food has great potential. $15 for small pot of cheese?? Not great value especially when after spending $70.00 before tip your starving and have to stop at extreme pizza on the way home.

I would recommend a real fondue experience with larger portions and heartier options such as broth and meal etc. Maybe they are going for the bar feel but when people are expecting dinner its very dissapointing.
author: Mindi M.

description:
We went with a group of 4 on a Tuesday hoping it would not be too busy.  We were wrong, all the tables were full and so was the bar.  We got some drinks and enjoyed them on the bench outside while we waited.  There was some confusion with the host that made our wait extremely long (we got skipped), but the server was extremely apologetic and got us a complimentary bottle of champaign for our trouble.  This is just new restaurant growing pains.  We understand

Anyway, the fondue is fantastic.  Really delicious and perfectly melted.  Its hard to get cheese to just the right consistency to stick to a mini pickle or an olive, but they pull it off.  The dipping options were fresh and varied.. bread, incredible roasted potatoes, veggies, grapes, etc.

Our party of 4 was starving, and our order of 3 cheese fondues, 1 chocolate and 2 salads was enough to fill us up.

The dark chocolate fondue was a consistency of brownie mix.. in a good way.  Really a decadent treat.

Beer and wine selections were excellent.

We will be back.
author: Troy S.

description:
Fondue Cowbow - I give you 4 stars for the potential you have but I had more of a 3 star experience, but likely because it was night 2 and you still need to work out your kinks. 

Great, reasonably priced wine list. I stuck to the rose bubbly for the duration of my experience, it was crisp, delicious, and not overpriced. 
Menu was pretty good although I didn't realize until after we were on to our dessert course that we weren't given all the sides that other people got. We ordered the "Quick Draw" and didn't get any potoates or little pickles :( Total bummer on that. The beet salad was very fresh and balanced, although very tiny. The bread we got for dipping was only OK, I feel like it could have been better. 

For dessert we tried the milk chocolate and white chocolate. The milk chocolate was yummy but the white chocolate was pretty runny and not thick at all. Plus the heat ended up burned the middle (it was boiling!) and I ate some of the burnt congealed chocolate. 

Service was really slow but like I said, they probably need some time to work it out. Cute place though and great to go with a friend or friends if you're not starving. I feel like it would be kind of difficult to go with a large group of people, so your best bet is to keep it small.
author: Lindsay A.

description:
Had a really great dinner here! I mean, you can't go too wrong with melted cheese.

We had the Traditional and the Outlaw (which was by far the table favorite). For dessert we had the dark chocolate and cayenne (the Happy Trails). Service was quick and very friendly. Loved the atmosphere too!
author: Veronica B.

description:
Definitely at least 4 stars, but I want to make sure to make up for the negative reviews so I'll give it 5. The food is really good! And the bad reviews all seem about the long wait, c'mon pretend hipsters, either go on a non-busy night or be patient! You never complain when you wait in line for an hour in the sun on a hot afternoon for bi-rite icecream when you go to Dolores park, do you?! :D

We went on a Sunday evening at six, the place was calm and the folks were really nice. Can't complain at all about the service, James is super friendly, they were always prompt about filling up our glasses of wine, and making sure our fondues arrived one after the other, and so on.. 

We were there for almost three hours, got a bottle of wine, then hung out sipping on that for a while, then finally ordered some really yummy jalapeno and mushroom fondues! It comes with lots of fun things like pickes, olives, grapes, roasted potatoes to dip in the cheese.. And dessert, oh man! The dark chocolate with cayenne! It is super spicy!!! and it's a must get!
author: Kaushal P.

description:
Last night a group of 6 adults and one non-adult had 7 of the 8 fondues on the menu. If math had been my major instead of English, I might be bothered to display that in percentages, but alas. My takes:

Traditional--nothing fancy; upstaged by the other savories
Outlaw--tasty, not spicy
Quick Draw--nice bite from the manchego
Rawhide--my favorite, though others felt it a bit salty

Surprisingly, in rank order for the sweet fondues:

Buck -A-Roo--first time since adulthood that milk chocolate beat dark chocolate
High Noon--up is down, day is night etc, in that the white chocolate was the overwhelming favorite of the table
Happy Trails--pull back on the cayenne and amp the flavor of the dark chocolate, please

Seven fondues were plenty for six hungry adults--not the kind of meal you can indulge in too often and still maintain lactose tolerance. We *could* have gotten away with six, but honestly, why would you? You're eating fondue, so just spear the bread and get over it.

Also, we appreciated the kind and attentive server who whisked us a plate of bread and bananas to shove in the screaming non-adult's mouth. Excellent, responsive service from everyone. 

Driving in from 85 degree weather, I was skeptical about summer love for fondue, but miracle happened...
author: Kitty B.

description:
What a little gem!  I came here with a few girlfriends and we loved it.  This place has a cool, comfortable, modern, western vibe without being cheesy or too into the theme.  The people who work here are really friendly and accommodating.  

The FOOD:  We ordered 2 savory fondues (the quick draw & the rawhide).  these two choices were more than enough food for 3 people!  They were more similar in taste than expected.
